movie_title: I don't feel at home in this world anymore. (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Essentially, The Most Hated Woman in America does far more harm than good in how it presents the story of Madalyn Murray O'Hair.
movie_title: The Most Hated Woman In America (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Tramps is overall a winning film, proving once again that some of the best romantic comedies can be light on plot: all we need is an excuse for beautiful people to fall in love.

Rules is entirely baffling. Is it a tale of Old Hollywood? Is it a biopic of Howard Hughes? Is it a love story? Unfortunately, it can never decide, so tries to be all of the above and therefore succeeds at none.
The performances are transfixing throughout. But it does not satisfy emotionally, as the ending of The Sense of an Ending makes no sense. It's a (Non)Sense of an Ending.
As a general rule poetry does not make good cinema, but this one succeeds more than most.

The world is populated by blandly one-dimensional characters. Evil is perpetrated by our old friend, Corporate Evil Man -- yes, still -- and everyone communicates via dialogue so stilted and ham-fisted it makes you die inside a little.
I won't describe the aliens in detail here because the reveal is 87.4 per cent of the fun. I will say only that they're monstrous but also strangely balletic and tender.
It's the kind of story that has been told countless times, and here it's told in such a perfunctory, plodding way that it brings nothing new to the party.

This film is beautiful to look at, but if it has anything to say about sex, violence, desire, it all passed me by. Rape should be shown on screen, if only to challenge it, but if this does any of that challenging, that too passed me by.
You will, I promise, be profoundly moved.
This is a deeply compassionate film that not only does astounding work on the being black, being gay front, but is also about anybody who feels they exist outside the world they've been born into.

It's serviceable. It won't be the biggest disappointment in your life. The story's too good for it to get away completely. But it's simplistic, exposition-heavy, joyless and focuses on the obstacles to their love rather than the love itself.
I've decided it probably is a failure, but that you haven't heard the last from Dolan.
movie_title: It's Only the End of the World (Juste la fin du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This has its visually wondrous moments, and the lead (Lewis MacDougall) is a true find, but there's too much bark, too little bite.
Silence is Martin Scorsese's film about Jesuit priests in 17th-century Japan whose faith is sorely tested, just as your patience will be sorely tested too.
It's psychologically thin, tiresomely hagiographic and doesn't answer any of the questions you'd like it to answer.
Was I riveted by Natalie Portman as Jackie Kennedy? I was... But was I aware it was Natalie Portman, Acting? Always. And there isn't much else here.
On to the characters, who were sad and despairing back in the day, but always empathetic and never victims. Here... well, I'm not that sure who they are.

It has its highly entertaining moments, and there is some fun to be had in McConaughey's madly over-zealous performance but it is derivative and there are so many storytelling impulses on the go that none has any hope of ever hitting home.
While all the cast are sublime, this is Bening's film. She is incredible. It is a performance of the utmost nuance.
La La Land with caveats is still more wonderful than almost anything else.
Most patient adults may want to strangle the impish Elmo within the first 10 minutes of this movie.
movie_title: The Adventures of Elmo in Grouchland (1999)

movie_review_blurb: What doesn't work is how it is so eager to frighten without a protagonist to root for.
It sails smoothly from start to finish and feels like a pleasant adventure, even if it is not particularly memorable.
The film does not feel like it gives sufficient exploration of the temptation of Christ, but there is no denying the deep spirituality and thought-provoking nature of it.
Unfortunately, the lack of development in the plot and characters make this romantic escape feel less than satisfying in the end.
Unfortunately, The Rezort is a film that wants to be taken seriously, but is so lacking in originality that it simply falls apart.
The jokes and story do not hold a candle to their predecessor, but there are enough funny and moving moments to make this a pretty solid family flick.
The theme of human enslavement to technology is still there, but Cell does not dive any further - besides the occasional reminder about the prevalence of telecommunication devices.
The movie is interesting but that is not nearly enough to entertain, even if only for 106 minutes.
movie_title: April and the Extraordinary World (Avril et le monde truqu√©) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Director James Wan, a veteran of the horror genre, has no problems torturing his viewers with tension before unleashing hell.
What saves the entire thing is Skarsgard, who steals the spotlight by striking the balance between a ruthless figure and a loving family man.
Even though fans will probably enjoy the rare glimpse of reclusive Prince frolicking on the big screen, better to buy the album (as well as Pandemonium by The Time) than to waste money on this dreck.
Surprisingly few surprises in this classic samurai costumer from Japan's dark iconoclast Takeshi Miike.
Breathtaking sets and effects give this youthful martial arts film a modern air.
movie_title: Detective Dee and the Mystery of the Phantom Flame (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Classy and professional throughout, the technical work gracefully holds all the threads together.

It is one of the few films so visually absorbing, felicitous shot after shot, that its emotional coldness is noticed only at the end, when all the plot twists are unraveled in a solid piece of thinking-man's entertainment for upmarket thriller audiences.

Huge immediacy and topicality are not inconsiderable virtues in a documentary attempting to tell the world some true things about the Arab spring as it played out in Egypt, ending in the arrest and trial of president Hosni Mubarak.
movie_title: In Tahrir Square: 18 Days Of Egypt's Unfinished Revolution (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A youthful, melancholy film that draws on literature and writing for its inspiration.
A hard-boiled Spanish police thriller about a good cop gone bad hits the genre spot.
Wim Wenders' stylish 3D mirrors the bizarrely captivating world of choreographer Pina Bausch.
Conveys a sense of the writer's personal life and his independent thinking, never banal and rarely disconnected from the world around him.
Director Ron Howard and his crew have worked hard to make Professor Robert Langdon's return a thrilling, faster-paced walk in the park.
A long, slow haul but for the willing, a haunting journey into the heart of darkness in Turkish Anatolia.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The film's pace races through events in a chain of escalating violence, tension, smoke and gunfire.
Ambitious and entertaining fantasy examines multiple lives and choices.
Historical drama set in the early days of the French revolution is intelligent Euro eye candy at its most lavish.
Modern love shifts from Hong Kong to Beijing in the successful sequel to Love in a Puff, a natural, light and convincing rom com very similar to the original Hong Kong hit.
Richard Coyle and a strong supporting cast lend interest to a London-set remake of Nicolas Winding Refn's 1996 Danish gangster thriller.
Live-action follow-up to "Persepolis" set in 1950s Iran blends humor and poetry with delightful artistry.
A disappointingly obvious follow-up to [Garrone's] unsparing criminal drama Gomorra...
Tensely involving Iranian drama with niche potential.
"Scheherazade, Tell Me a Story" is a powerful indictment of misogyny that overturns stereotypes about Egypt through the dramatic stories women recount on a television show.
A superbly guilty pleasure for a rainy day.
After years of working on photography, poetry and more experimental films, Abbas Kiarostami makes an engaging return to narrative cinema in a delicate, bittersweet comedy set in romantic Italy.
Resonating with layers of personal and political meaning, the messy aftermath of the Egyptian revolution is captured with immediacy and excitement.
The promise of the whimsical title "Police, Adjective" is fulfilled at the end of this likable, cinematically sophisticated but slow-moving police procedural.
Both spectacular and pious, "Tsar" positions itself between Sergei Eisenstein's "Ivan the Terrible" and Andrei Tarkovsky's "Andrei Rublev," though without their originality and inspiration.
Constructed like an eerie, metaphorical thriller, this tense, riveting character study offers viewers nearly two hours of emotions with a stunning pay-off no one will be expecting.
A superb work of Japanese fantasy from animation wizard Miyazaki that transcends age barriers.

Director John Hillcoat has performed an admirable job of bringing Cormac McCarthy's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel to the screen as an intact and haunting tale, even at the cost of sacrificing color, big scenes and standard Hollywood imagery.
This is a typical Moore oeuvre: funny, often over the top and of dubious documentation, but with strongly made points that leave viewers much to ponder and debate after they walk out of the theater.
With material like this, one would have liked a more incisive comedy to materialize around the decline and fall of the New Age movement.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An exciting thriller from Argentina capable of crossing borders.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Dazzling nature doc chooses poetry and wonder over storytelling and effects.
A heady mix of deadpan humor that boldly uses such topics as pedophilia, race and terrorism to plead the need for forgiveness at a personal and national level.

Seven years after Divine Intervention, director Elia Suleiman returns with more humorous-sad stories from his native Palestine, couched in the ironic autobiographical language at which he is grandly adept.
[A] long, elegantly shot, sporadically involving Japanese film.
This bold piece of docu-fiction, an open protest against censorship and the repression of individual liberties, will no doubt make waves in Iran.
movie_title: No One Knows About Persian Cats (Les Chats Persans) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A political film with a message of hope, on the obvious side.
Despite its subject, Coppola seems to be exercising more of her European than American sensibility in the small-scale intimacy of this portrait.
Joaquin Phoenix and Casey Affleck push the edges of celebrity spoof in a mockumentary worth watching.
A realistic slice of pioneer life that offers a disquieting alternative vision of America's most mythic location.
Far less daring than her 1999 Titus, which took an electrifying, stylized approach of a lesser-known play, The Tempest in comparison looks disappointingly middle-of-the-road.
Potiche has plenty of contemporary sparkle and life, courtesy of a masterful central performance by grande dame Catherine Deneuve as an oppressed bourgeois housewife who finds liberation.
This is less a film about terrorists than an intimate portrait of boys growing up in a toxic environment.
Irresistible trashy fun in a cross-genre free-for-all.
movie_title: Why Don't You Play in Hell? (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Confused, at times naive story-telling eventually gives way to a powerful dramatic finale, but one so downbeat it leaves a bitter taste in the mouth...
Inert Canadian-French drama attempts to explore the motivation behind a suicide bombing.
A humorous, humanistic approach enlivens an inventive documentary feature about people living around Rome's ring road
Something of a roller coaster and fairly bumpy, the ride is the problem here.
A film about the beauty of flight and the prelude to war, whose astonishing visuals shout that life is wonderful.
The first feature ever shot in Saudi Arabia is a winner directed by a woman, Haifaa Al Mansour.
Stephen Frears returns to top form in a touching, at times funny true story of grave injustice and a mother's search for closure.
A sometimes fascinating, sometimes not, four-hour visit to the Berkeley campus offers insights into what the great, sprawling public university is today.
Though it's packed with adorable tykes and more than a few strong scenes, even Kore-eda fans may feel a let-down with a lovely film that makes little emotional connection

As hauntingly strange as it is inconclusive and frustrating, Enemy, directed by Denis Villeneuve (Incendies), is one of the more head-scratching additions to the doppelganger genre. Yet it will certainly have its fans.
Enjoyable enough, this colorfully local, nostalgia-tinged tale focuses on the Hong Kong years of an older, gentlemanly kung fu master.

A serious European financial thriller is something of a novelty, and Costa-Gavras, the militant film master par excellence, shows perfect timing in his ambitious Capital, a film that lingers in the memory in spite of being rather irritating to watch.
This big-budget English-language co-production shows that Europeans can compete in the sci-fi realm where high production values are king.

Zeiler, a relatively unknown actor outside of German TV, energetically fills the main role with quick intelligence and unflagging self-confidence, which helps the viewer negotiate the dangerous ground he walks on.
Sensitive lensing and acting render an unusual story of brotherly love touching in a promising first film.
Sure-footed scripting and a stand-out performance by Luminita Gheorghiu freshen a potentially pat subject.
Dustin Hoffman's directing debut about retired musicians in the third act of their lives has a winning, classy charm for older audiences.

Geoffrey Rush brings striking depth of character to a classic Old World mystery set against the sophisticated backdrop of Europe's art auctions, with charming input from Jim Sturgess and Donald Sutherland.
Serious story-telling is about the only thing that unites these short stories.
An irresistible treat for connoisseurs and the uninitiated alike, pic will be a bracing surprise for anyone who has forgotten how exciting music, dance and voice can be.
Dynamic chase film hits all the right buttons to fascinate edge-of-seat cop op addicts.
Promises a lot but lacks conviction, feeling like a case study with a very arbitrary ending.
Images and metaphors whimsicially combine in a fine, fast-flowing documentary introducing the Baha'i faith.
Referencing without imitating Fellini, Sorrentino offers an amusing update on Italian society at the end of a cycle.
Michael Nyman's sweepingly majestic score lends an epic dimension, which feels right alongside the straight-forward passion depicted by an evenly balanced, top-drawer cast.
A dizzying explosion of an Indian gangster film, whose epic structure and colorful, immoral killers capture the imagination for over five hours.
Rosales continues his exploration of the way unexpected acts of violence brutally alter the course of human lives.
Ward ... flounders around for an effective tone between comedy and drama in his first solo effort.
Dan Algrant's lyrical recreation of a father-son relationship seen over time, through memory and music, has a sense of urgent originality that works even apart from its great Tim Buckley score.
Fantastic visuals and non-stop action make for a spectacular, romantic Chinese CGI feast.
movie_title: Bai she chuan shuo (The Sorcerer and the White Snake) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A tremendously realistic disaster movie has an intense emotional payoff.
There is surprisingly little emotional resonance with the well-drawn and acted characters, making it a tiring two and a half hour trek for filmgoers who don't have a stake in the history it recounts.
Consummate acting helps ease a painful watch, as Michael Haneke describes the ultimate test of love in a profoundly honest study of sickness and dying.
The fresh and simple story will win its share of young fans, though it lacks the disturbing adult elements might have attracted older audiences.
Strained attempt at WWII tragi-comedy isn't funny.
The sensitively imagined story of a child soldier in Africa makes War Witch a genre benchmark and a breakout work for writer-director Kim Nguyen.
Meshkini communicates a personal vision in terms all women (and certainly many men) can feel deeply.
movie_title: Roozi ke zan shodam (The Day I Became a Woman) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: With such an in-house cast of extended Coppola family sparklers, one would think things couldn't go too wrong in the comedy department, but they have little chance to oil the wheels of a creaky script written around Sheen.
movie_title: A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The tense dialogue between East and Post post-9/11 is turned into a tense, often gripping duet between a young Muslim professor and American reporter.
Finely wrought and acted psychological drama cleverly plays on the repressed violence and projections of a Turkish family on holiday.

There is just about enough narrative to hold interest, while the lyrical camerawork, constantly in motion, blurred images and all, offers a single emotion that is impossible to stretch over a feature-length film.
A grungy, dark police procedural set in motion by a little girl's kidnapping, Ugly has few discernible auteur touches to set it apart from standard genre fare.
They are of varying interest, but the overall impression they leave is watching a Bollywood sampler without the song and dance, a committee project with an impressive budget but little heart.
A strong storyline about the West Bank and its endless cycle of violence leaves interpretation up to the viewer.
This simple, repetetive tale has a mesmerizing quality able to hook audiences from beginning to end.
movie_title: The Story of Qiu Ju (Qiu Ju da guan si) (1992)

movie_review_blurb: The lifelong shame and trauma experienced by the victims of childhood incest are grippingly dramatized by Cristina Comencini, consummate mistress of Italian family drama, in Don't Tell, probably her most successful film.
The film has major problems blending the strong social theme of exploitation and white slavery with Tornatore's noirish screenplay, full of holes and improbabilities.
Radiates a warm humanity and uplifts the spirit.
British documakers Kim and Florence Ayisi present a surprisingly positive portrait of the justice system in a small town in Cameroon.
The dialogue has a pleasing low-key realism that complements Soderbergh's understated direction, though one can sense a firm hand always guiding the straightforward story.
A powerful portrait of the Spanish spirit, particularly the gypsy culture of Andalusia.
Shows little interest in making sense.
Marcelo Gomes makes an impressive if sober feature helming debut in Cinema, Aspirin and Vultures.
movie_title: Cinema, Asprin And Vultures (cinema, Aspirinas E Urubus) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: In its quiet way, Taraneh touches the hot issues -- jail, divorce, teenage love, unwed maternity -- and comes up with a convincing, positive answer to all.
Though the storyline is dirt simple (can friendship outlive jealousy?) and not particularly meaningful or involving, the action in this character-driven film is scintillatingly sexy.

A contrived, rather unpleasant English-lingo thriller set in the Netherlands and Luxembourg, Moonlight takes a precocious love story between a young rich girl and an Afghan boy to kinky limits where few auds will want to tread.

A study in courage and harrowing portrait of a 14-year-old boy who works in a Bolivian silver mine, The Devil's Miner is an unforgettable journey through hell under the earth, where Satan is worshipped as king.
A large cast of youthful performers, including the director and scriptwriters, at first seem awkwardly lifted from the stage, but begin to emerge as believable characters by and by.
Its undeniable appeal lies in shocking frankness shackled to irony, a combo that should attract indie lovers with psychoanalytic leanings and droll senses of humor.
Powerfully co-directed by Michael Winterbottom and Mat Whitecross, the film has a winning combo of excitement and topicality.
Besides the fine Bakovic, the cast does a splendid job fleshing out unconventional roles.
The pic's torturously slow pace turns an earnest effort into a tedious aesthetic exercise.
The Yacoubian Building distinguishes itself both as the most expensive Egyptian film ever made and, despite its nearly three-hour running time, one of the most watchable.
Though weak in the drama department, the story of a brother and sister who love each other but have different political ideas and personal agendas effectively captures the tension of the time.
A frustratingly slow drama.
Promises much more than it delivers.
Comedy veteran Paolo Virzi brings a light helming touch to a story with a lot to say about contemporary Italy.

Somewhere between Monty Python, Jacques Tati and a slideshow of New Yorker cartoons, this critique of life's cruel inconsistency confirms the French co-directors' gift for reinterpreting surrealism in a humorously modern key.
Though the comedy's not all that sparkling and the cast generally uninspired, pic is pretty to look at.
The tight pacing of Michael Hudecek and Nadine Muse's editing keeps the story fluid and focused but very concise, commanding audience attention from start to finish.
A powerful reflection on the beginning of Hitler's Final Solution is seen through the intelligent, sardonic eyes of an aged eyewitness.
Bringing a fiery warmth and accessibility to the central role, [Hayek] proves a good match for the artist as she depicts Kahlo's indomitable will to live, love and paint.
Sharif sparkles as a Turkish grocery store owner and self-styled philosopher who brings sunshine into the life of a lonely boy.
movie_title: Monsieur Ibrahim et les fleurs du Coran (Monsieur Ibrahim) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Timely and thought-provoking, if a bit rambling.
movie_title: Forget Baghdad: Jews and Arabs - The Iraqi Connection (2003)

Most successful are the mini-comedies with a loose punchline, while others barely qualify as character sketches.
The two things that keep the film from falling into laughable melodrama are its continual inventions on a stylistic level ... and the exceptional level of acting.
One has the feeling the director has let himself go off the deep end regarding the romantic and idealizing tendencies that, for better or worse, characterize much of his work.
Though the film's multiple strands strain to blend, they do give the protags' ill-fated romance a level of deeper, more involving meaning.

Takes the viewer on a mysterious and sporadically fascinating trip into the darkness of the human heart and Thai legend, but only after an hour of a weakly structured story about two young men who are attracted to each other.
Upscale auds will enjoy the film's affectionate portrait of the diva, coupled with a selection of her great recordings and Zeffirelli's dazzling, fictional stagings of Carmen.

A film destined to divide Manoel de Oliveira's fans but also to win him new ones.
Twin Sisters has the engrossing quality of a big historical novel and about the same level of sentimental artistry.

The sensitive dual female role for femme lead Radha Mitchell stirs memories of complex Allen heroines from Annie Hall on down, even if the action is dispersed via a larger ensemble cast which he currently favors.
A kinky Brazilian offering packed with good ideas in a sophisticated horror vein, but disappointing in the unraveling.
The connections [Kiarostami] makes between his cinema and Italian neo-realism will interest scholars, students and fledgling directors.
A fascinating if somewhat morbid study.
Both intensely exciting for its cinematic inventions and terribly uninvolving on emotional and dramatic levels.
This enjoyable French pic welds together drama, melodrama and comedy in a blend with potentially strong European audience appeal.
Emir Kusturica's epic black comedy about Yugoslavia from 1941 to 1992 is a three-hour steamroller circus that leaves the viewer dazed and exhausted, but mightily impressed.
An engaging if uneven tale that outstays its welcome, Sonhos de peixe describes the life and loves of a teenage lobster diver from a poor Brazilian fishing village.
The buoyant little comedy 12:08 East of Bucharest puts its finger on the problem in the best tradition of East European humor, savvy but concrete, gentle but sharp as a knife.

movie_review_blurb: A fairly successful attempt at satire, though given the subject, there's a lot of darkness under the carpet.
Apart from a few tour de force dance scenes, though, the rhythm tends to drag.
One of those rare docs capable of holding its own in an official selection of fiction films.

Following her more on-target I Like to Work (Mobbing) about workplace harassment, and her delicate Italo Svevo adaptation My Father's Words, this film comes as something of a let-down from the wide-ranging director.
Though it sounds like an offbeat idea even for horror fans, the tech work is so well done that it could disarm unwary buffs attracted by the campy title.
movie_title: Dracula: Pages From a Virgin's Diary (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Sensitive, delicate and involving...

Unreal characters and story shackle this gloomy tale of unconventional love between a long-lost brother and sister.
Splashy, noisy and downright fun.
A tense documentary with multiple layers of meaning.
[A] beautifully crafted and lively romp around the 1880s stage world.
Stumbles into a lame love story and ends in a conventional shootout and bloodbath.
A film whose lightness of touch rides a wave of family conflict to perfectly balance smiles and tears.

Tensely action-packed and muscularly directed by Kathryn Bigelow, this tale of an elite U.S. army bomb disposal unit in Baghdad is a familiar story in new clothes, targeted at the young male demographic.
Before the Rain is a visually and narratively stunning tale in three parts, set between modern London and the timeless hills of Macedonia, in former Yugoslavia
A morbidly fascinating prep school tragedy which also is a stylistically uncompromisingly vision of hypocritical America.
Powerful, emotional filmmaking and acting give a lift to the familiar women-in-prison film.
The story, spiked with gentle humor, moves smoothly through the standard tropes of Iranian art house cinema.
A surprisingly deep tale about a middle-aged German couple discovering love on the brink of death.
The pic should suck even landlubbers into a whirlpool of gripping adventure, overblown ambitions and sheer human folly.
A somber, beautifully acted reflection on the barbarity of war and the bestiality of man, which only enormous compassion can redeem.
A fast-moving, engrossing multiple-character drama that brings the AIDS crisis of the 1980s into laser focus.
The idea of linking the vampire myth to the city's depressing sociopolitical climate is more intriguing than film itself.
Ambitiously trying to blend the joys of growing up with the melancholy of living in a country under one of the worst dictatorships in Eastern Europe, this warm story does have a tendency to ramble.
movie_title: The Way I Spent the End of the World (Cum mi-am petrecut sfarsitul lumii) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Killing makes a man a man in the puzzling To Get to Heaven You Have to Die, an artfully lensed but psychologically unpersuasive initiation tale from Tajikistan.
movie_title: To Get to Heaven, First You Have to Die (Bihisht faqat baroi murdagon) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Rather miraculously, pic succeeds in painlessly educating its viewers about global politics and economics while it describes contemporary Africa with freshness and clarity.

Though functional on its own terms, this fourth feature by Israel Adrian Caetano feels hollow at the core, leaving a feeling of lingering disappointment over a missed opportunity to probe recent history.
A tiresomely silly film that suffers from overacting and an overwritten script.
At a two-hour-plus running time, only the most stout-hearted fans of cold-blooded art cinema will stick around to find out how much misery awaits the unwary and not too bright heroine.
When the master of French thrillers Claude Chabrol meets the mistress of English suspense fiction Ruth Rendell, the result is a potent if very classic blend.
A galloping fable full of offbeat characters and entertaining moments.
Much of the pic's strength is in leaning on the frail shoulders of newcomer Dorotheea Petre, who is insightful and refreshingly contemporary as a boy-girl-woman searching for her identity.
A passionate outcry for peace and justice in America that becomes deeply involving by the final climactic scene, overlaid with one of RFK's most stirring speeches.
Oliveira's short but sweet rumination on growing old and the fading of sexual desire is not only high-concept, but one of his most watchable.
Almost a sinful pleasure is Andrey Zhegalov's striking widescreen cinematography.

Using a simple storytelling style that grows stronger with each passing scene, Dry Season draws the viewer into its small two-character drama set in post-war Chad, while it offers a deep reflection on injustice and frustrated revenge.
Sophisticated auds will enjoy this thoroughly modern spoof on masculine fixations, played out in frank, realistic dialogue.
The even-handed film is sympathetic to the Cuban revolution in its initial stages, then slowly swings around to reveal the 'skeleton of a dream' that the society has become.
movie_title: The Sugar Curtain (El Telon de azucar) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A surprisingly layered vehicle for a maniacally conniving Richard Gere, backed up by a superb Alfred Molina as his accomplice.
Audiences hooked on Persian mainstream will devour this irreverent romantic comedy, spiced with saucy dialogue that spoofs traditional gender roles through gritted teeth.
Containing a bare minimum of suspense and excitement, story unspools like a shaggy dog story missing the punchline.

Contagiously upbeat The Orchestra of Piazza Vittorio is a rousing call to arms for world-music aficionados, with strong appeal to those who believe in the mini-miracles of neighborhood cultural initiatives.
A film that touches the heartstrings as it brings home the cruel class distinctions that poison Indian society.
Its astute use of a modern deep-focus, 3D idiom creates the engrossing immediacy of a large-scale disaster film.
One waits uneasily for the story to turn dark, but instead the film just runs out of energy in its second half.
The sinister interest a Nazi physician takes in a 12-year-old girl and her family makes for a chilling, original tale.
There seems to be something missing here.
A high-adrenaline tale of fighting, shooting, stabbing and killing interrupted by quiet stretches of backstory and character development.
The ravishing "natural" beauty of the scenes has been masterfully contrived by the camera lens, aperture and framing.
It has its harrowing moments, but the psychological thriller Jasmine is an impenetrable mystery for most of its running time, and deliberately so.
A thriller made riveting by an emotional performance from Diane Kruger.
A masterfully made psychological thriller in the traditional mode.

movie_review_blurb: Its visual style and pacing make as much of an impression as the head-shaking story.
Not an easy watch but a highly rewarding one.
A short and sweet divertissement with a few profound punchlines.
Lipstick is audaciously outspoken about women's sexual desires and fantasies, both visually and verbally.
[A] long, engrossing, visually stunning documentary ...

Both Redford and Fonda are charming, delicate and convincing as Addie Moore and Louis Waters, the couple who find each other at the tail end of their lives. They are directed with sophistication and without a drop of melodrama or sentimentality ...
Each character resonates as a problematic individual whose foolishness escalates first into drama, then tragedy.
Bold modernist cinema at its most harrowing.
A road movie short on comedy and drama should at least offer a keen level of observation, but here insight is scarce and emotional resonance is faint.
Lensed with great sensitivity and style and superbly acted, it has one drawback for Western audiences in its perplexing plot points based on the local culture and customs.
Never talking down to his audience, [Wiseman] rather pulls them up to an intellectual level where other filmmakers fear to go.
movie_title: Ex Libris: New York Public Library (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A complex and engrossing examination of truth.

Nicchiarelli dives deeply into the life of a tragic but remarkable woman, memorably portrayed by Danish actress and singer Trine Dyrholm as an unpleasant, hurtful junkie plagued with memories and regrets.
An audacious, if somewhat didactic, debut.
An uncompromising drama from one of Iran's most outspoken directors.

If Grassadonia and Piazza had simply retold the story, it would have been gripping enough, but they deepen the intensity and widen the meaning by letting the tale unfold in a strange filmic space between cruel reality and ghostly fantasy.

First-rate Japanese anime is a taste that anyone can acquire in the time it takes to watch a film like this, and it should confirm Shinkai's reputation to genre-lovers around the world, who know his poetry-inspired The Garden of Words.
Using just the right, understated dose of symbolism, the film takes on an especially frightening quality like in a fairy tale whose monster is invisible and invincible.
The film's strong point is the unquestionable beauty of the imagery, filmed over a four-year period in the national parks and animal reserves of Poland, Romania, Norway, Holland and Scotland.
Compared to some of the trashy Japanese slasher fare that passes as entertainment, Museum stands hair on edge without resorting to tons of fake blood or gruesomely realistic offenses to the body.
Irresistibly laugh-out-loud and feel-good.
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

An edgy mix of structured narrative and improv.
Holland, who had a hit a few years back with the HBO Europe spy series set during the Cold War, Burning Bush, is a mistress of spare, elegant shots that show just enough to advance the story.
At once historically impeccable and a filmic disappointment.

movie_review_blurb: Beautiful to look at and strangely haunting.

[An] involving, fable-like drama.

Solid, straightforward and touching.

What seems meant as a scorching indictment of American injustice and prejudice, or perhaps the searing character study of a cornered man, just ends up looking wishy-washy and old-fashioned.

nfortunately, the awkwardly titled Every Thing Will Be Fine seems more like a showcase for expressive camerawork pushing the limits of cinematography than anything else.

Playing jokes on old people isn't funny.

movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Comparisons aside, this film works because it works as a film - from its artful interweaving and overlapping of sound and image, to its masterful construction of tension, and its naturalistic performances.

A shift in focus from a potentially jittery thriller to a humdrum, psychological analysis of a dislocated family becomes the narrative driving force and given the rich backdrop, it appears a great opportunity has been severely missed.
He may have moved outside to the relative freedom of the streets, however the continuation of the same oppressive narrative persists and he is going to still defy it.
Rupert Evans' performance as David is alarming in the shift from unassuming and tender husband and father to demonic neurotic and delusional obsessive.

The introduction of too many ill-conceived sub-plots fails to enhance or execute the essential tenets of the narrative, only serving to detract and distract from the film's overall philosophy, lacking the sharp, subversive edge required for black comedy.

Situating death as the catalyst to action whereby legends, apparitions and spirits mobilize the command to vengeance, Fraser's narrative teems and trounces with relentless bloodshed, slaughter, violence and gore.
Without a high level of mystical intrigue and unnerving eeriness fuelling the story, the plot fails to ignite on a level that would allow for audience investment and identification.
While entering the minds of the perpetrators in The Act of Killing was motivated by action, looking at the legacy of genocide through the eyes of its survivors drives The Look of Silence.

While there is occasional delight of artful satire, fanciful farce, psychological undercurrent and political breadth, it soon becomes evident, as the intricate subplots and subtexts unfold, Ozon has rather overstretched himself again.
Makhmalbaf refrains from idealising a portrait of human anxiety but rather delineates the interchangeability between administering oppression and seeking opportunistic revenge.

Disheartening and uncomfortable at times, The Salt of the Earth forces its audience to confront images of a brutal, sometimes forgotten past, deconstructing any notion of an idealized, romantic history.

The pace of the film is slow, tense and anxious, built upon a motivation for revenge between two antithetical men, who are united through a shared destructive ideology, cementing the absurdity of human ideals.
Vanderbilt's attempts at interrogation simply do not get under the skin and fail to penetrate the cynical cycle of corruption and cover-ups, so palpably executed in Spotlight.
Approaching contentious topics with clarity and tact and attempting to find the correct balance between irony and outright offence within a comedic context can often be a tricky affair.
Song of the Sea is a magical feast of visual delights, narrative intrigue and nostalgic revisionism that will appeal to the inner child of all ages.
Executing the hyperactivity of a whirlwind career blighted by controversy and suspicion, The Program pulsates with furious pace, explosive energy and a razor-sharp visual style.

Gillen portrays Carver as a somewhat latter-day Hamlet; an essentially benevolent man who struggles to retain his sanity as he seeks to apprehend his bizarre, fragmented reality through grief and psychological hostility.
Paper Souls suffers from a severe identity crisis.

Cooper's cinematic scrapbook captures a relentless whirlwind of explosive rock history, in which a non-linear narrative and slick cinematography rollicks furiously through the decades, rooting the audience directly in the band's volcanic timeline.

A compelling and propulsive no-holds-barred interpretation, Suffragette does not shy away from accentuating the extreme subversive tactics employed by the bastions of the women's movement in the face of frenzied, brutal opposition.
Jupiter Ascending fails to offer its audiences anything other than a one-dimensional and disappointingly regressive visual saga of sci-fi fantasy and 1950s pulp.
While the Scottish landscape has never looked more enticing, sadly, majestic mountains and sweeping seascapes cannot plaster over the uncomfortable cracks in McFarlane's feature debut.
Daniel Wolfe is quick to delineate the gendered nature of honour killings and a cultural framework that deifies a son and demonises a daughter.

The film's reluctance to overinvest in its religious significance will certainly not satisfy the spiritual nor will it come as a welcome relief to the skeptical, placing the overall audience in a state of limbo.

Despite a formidable and kaleidoscopic performance, there is a sense that the themes of human frailty and the will to heal that inform the film's narrative are beyond Aniston's abilities as a serious dramatic actress.

Narratively continuous to the original film but slightly disregarding its two sequels, Jurassic World is a spectacular rush of furious energy, spellbinding awe and alarming terror from beginning to end.
The tone of the film is analogically morbid and pessimistic and affecting and sanguine, emphasising the axiomatic transitory condition of mortality.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It is all rather too restraint and temperate an affair, hugely lacking the decadence and opulence of French aristocratic life.

Danny Collins is, at times, an engaging and downright hilarious comedy drama that will have you laughing through the tears but this is simply owing to the sublime performances from its cast...

Ariane Labed is a revelation as Alice, whose nuanced yet emotionally charged performance, not only anchors the core narrative but navigates the philosophical subtexts with both a skittish mischievousness and an intense urgency...
While the film is arguably no better or worse than its literary source, it does shatter the fantasies of sexual desire and sexual pleasure constructed within the novel.
Regardless of its gleaming production and costume design, smooth technical style and frisky musical score, Focus is largely seductive because Smith and Robbie are the seducers.

Such an inflexible adaptation results in a rather half-hearted screenplay that lacks the energy of its source novel, failing to arouse or thrill on any level.
A good performance from Breslin keeps tension alive, but hope for a really scary and inventive fright dies screaming in the basement.

There are slapdash references to many Hindi films past. If you are a Bollywood junkie, there is much dialogue you have heard before. You can almost finish the lines before the character on screen does.
It left me strangely underwhelmed.
This is a rare movie that, in our world of instant endorsements and fleeting moments of fame, has the power of staying with us. Maybe because it feels real.

While director Nishikant Kamat's direction needs some help in the first half in particular, there is nothing to fault in writer Jeethu Joseph's original story, which is the stuff cult classics are made of.

A campus drama-cum-whodunit that's obvious and exploitative even by low-bar youthpic standards.
Just middling funny, with no truly memorable high points and a sum impact that goes poof! before you've left the parking garage.
Trying to plumb beneath the usual emotional shallows of twentysomething L.A. gay life, Holding Trevor sometimes succeeds, but mostly comes off as a vanity project for writer-star Brent Gorski.
Daryl Wein's engrossing portrait of Richard Berkowitz is freshly engaging largely due to the subject himself.

Allowing auds sufficient retro-aristo-lifestyle sumptuousness for their dollar, yet exhibiting admirable, intelligent directorial restraint, this Brideshead is mainstream arthouse fare par excellence.
Midnight Kiss is one of those movies that gradually charms the viewer into strong identification with initially off-putting characters.
movie_title: In Search of a Midnight Kiss (2008)

movie_review_blurb: T&D offers good-natured, confidently executed splatstick whose frequent hilarity suffers only from peaking too early.
While offering a glimpse of stage routines, pic consists mostly of lively shop talk.
Pic duly places less emphasis on narrative than on the sort of surreal set pieces that might have worked better in the graphic-novel form.
Ninety minutes of Crocker's antics constitutes a portrait both exhaustive and frankly exhausting. But Zoo's larger ideas and idiosyncratic assembly retain interest
Hindsight allows David France's stirring How to Survive a Plague a concise overview's clarity and an epic narrative shape, with a happy ending to boot.
The segments vary in quality and the whole overstays its welcome at nearly two hours.
A potent snapshot of a potential future for many American cities.
A polished, watchable genre entertainment that nonetheless lacks the inspired dialogue and situations needed to make a memorable impression.
The low-key drama is well-crafted and likable as far as it goes, but there's not enough narrative impetus or depth to maintain more than passing viewer interest.
It doesn't take long for the absurdist humor to pall among a pileup of nonsensical ideas that would be funnier if grounded in a less hazy concept.
A deeper glimpse of the San Diego indie-rock scene around him might have made Brook's self-absorbed resentment less overbearing.
For a Good Time, Call... doesn't rise much above sitcom level in material or execution, but provides enough laughs and goodwill to be disarmingly entertaining.
This crude, shrill day in the life of three ill-matched Manhattan women will prove as irksome to most viewers as it is to the protags.
A likably low-key docudrama set in an attractive area of politically turbulent Kashmir.
Results are offbeat and amusing, but also a bit thin as the whole essentially amounts to one long shaggy-dog joke.
This teen romance proves perilously short on substance, insight and novelty, unless you count its characters being afflicted with a case of Juno mouth.
Searching for Sugar Man is a winning musical detective story about a failed, forgotten early '70s rocker who became a huge success halfway across the world.
Much of this is "stranger than fiction," all of it as engrossing as a flavorsome, twisty literary novel.
Innocuous and predictable but pleasant enough.
A creditable if familiar portrait of one aspiring-actor newbie's disillusioning wade into the rough waters of Hollywood.

Producer Charles Evans Jr.'s directorial debut finds an engrossing suspense angle in the involvement of Victor DeNoble, an idealistic scientist-turned-whistleblower whose suppressed corporate research became the bombshell catalyst in that struggle.

The more difficult characters here (all female) and resulting character dynamics are so consistently shrill that the pic feels a bit too one-dimensional and cruel to leave the small-tragedy aftertaste it could have.
This somber drama is well crafted and watchable but lacks the distinctive story content, style and standout performances to become more than a serviceable reboot of familiar ideas.
The late Chogyam Trungpa's very colorful life makes for a most engaging narrative here.
[A] thinly amusing tale with not-especially-appealing characters.
Jason Cohn and Bill Jersey's sprightly documentary weighs its subjects' unique accomplishments and widespread influence while probing a relationship more complex than its sunny public face indicated.
movie_title: Eames: The Architect And The Painter (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A starry cast and glossier production values simply work against the black-and-white original's strengths in this stillborn thriller.

Whether it's a product of the city's laid-back, party-hearty nature or a fault of the filmmaking, Sons makes for a pleasant sit but doesn't really have the substance to deliver the aimed-for tenor of inspirational struggle.
Campbell's career and influence encompass much wider fields of interest than are considered here, despite the pic's colorful surface.
Jonathan Segal's polished sophomore feature effectively grows more serious as it confronts the already grieving hero with the imminent loss of a second parent.

This tale of two elementary-school brothers plotting to end the physical separation their parents' divorce has forced on them effortlessly pulls off the naturalism and charm desired from material that might have easily curdled into calculated preciousness.
The material itself has a formulaic solo-bioplay rhythm neither performer nor director can fully elude.
A satisfying wartime espionage drama focused on little-noted intersections between Arabic emigres and the French Resistance.
An engrossing study in the communication possible (and sometimes near-impossible) between man and beast.

The first nonfiction feature dedicated to Romani victims, this globe-trotting debut effort by helmer Aaron Yeger and his producing team offers a vivid mix of visual evidence, historical commentary and survivor testimonies.

The process recorded by helmer Amir Bar-Lev holds attention with its peek at the widely ranging personalities, work methods and expertise demonstrated by musicians of different generations and varying experience.
Surviving Progress offers a cinematic wakeup call so cogent and non-didactic even Tea Partyers would be hard-pressed to shrug it off.
Hit-and-miss in terms of verbal wit and individual gags. But package moves along quickly, and overall concept remains amusing even when there's a dud moment or three.
It's consistent with its predecessor as a somewhat awkward translation of Ayn Rand's 1957 novel to our current era, handled with bland telepic-style competency.
It's a solid, fairly even-handed spur for discussion that will be particularly welcome in classroom settings.
A catchy but irrelevant title is the first of many problems with Excuse Me for Living, which throws together a lot of superficially flashy elements that never gel in any organic way.
[Adds] additional layers of self-consciousness to a story that was already pretty derivative.
[A] by-the-numbers slasher pic.
A rock-solid verite docu.
The result is at once skillfully observed and a bit so-what.

Though myriad aspects of its story have already been probed in greater depth elsewhere, Frances Causey and Donald Goldmacher's Heist is well timed as a one-stop summary of reasons for ordinary Americans to be furious at our financial systems.
movie_title: Heist: Who Stole The American Dream (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Nick Murphy's bigscreen directorial debut has good atmospherics that only go so far to prop up a mystery whose overdue explanation is convoluted and underwhelming.
The briskly edited docu seldom stops long enough to let Joe's new friends (identified only by first name) make anything beyond the most superficial impressions.
Much of this makes little sense, but it's hard to care.
An engaging subject and a seldom-scrutinized athletic competition make Julie Wyman's documentary a fun watch, even though there's ultimately not a great deal of narrative drive or deeper insight.
Landing between the twee, naturalistic and formulaic, Sassy Pants settles for cute, taking too few gambles to make a more lasting impression.
[An] engaging mix of diaristic, interview-based and whimsical elements.
movie_title: OC87: The Obsessive Compulsive, Major Depression, Bipolar, Asperger's Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An attempted Scorsese-esque crime epic that too often feels like an underdeveloped outline.
Funny and fresh.
This somber, somewhat emotionally distant effort lacks the operatic sweep its tragic family-epic material seems to cry for.
movie_title: The Beginning and the End (Principio y fin) (1993)

movie_review_blurb: Tale of two Angelenos succumbing to mutual passion under difficult circumstances is enjoyable if unsubtle in its first half, then takes a long time stumbling toward an inevitable conclusion in the second.
The packaging is so intelligently resourceful that most viewers will enjoy the ride regardless of its enigmatic destination.
A low-pulse thriller that evaporates from memory with the last credit.

Summerour's debut feature is a richly atmospheric drama that, despite its grisly hook, is ultimately far less interested in its tale's suspense/horror aspects than in how such a public shock affects and reveals the character of local citizenry.

While the premise feels a bit thin and the overall progress never strays far from fish-out-of-water formula, the execution is consistently ingratiating, even when it frustrates by raising ideas that go undeveloped.
There are no surprises here, with father-son crisis and reconciliation, scaled-down quasi-Bollywood production numbers and the climactic big game all arriving on cue.
Theoretical laughter, tears and maudlin contrivance ensue.
It's no Cape Fear, but it gets the job done with a certain bloody efficiency.

The script unfortunately suffers from its own case of arrested development, barely getting out of the gate before stalling, and never building enough laughs or narrative impetus to justify feature length.
Maintaining an admirably straight face, this fist-flying flashback is good fun for fanboy types who take its myriad absurdities with the requisite grain of salt.
Despite a decent premise, the pic's pedestrian execution and uninvolving characters make it a passable time-filler at best.
Formulaic, functional guys'-night-in entertainment.
These japes only do a disservice to the film's many serious allegations.
The difficulties of adapting idiosyncratic literature to the screen are all too apparent in The Trouble With Bliss.
Assembly is smooth, highlighted by a treasure trove of hitherto little-seen archival performance footage going back more than 50 years.
While it starts out well, Bobcat Goldthwait's black comedy struggles to maintain focus as it turns into a road trip of diminishing rewards in satirical and narrative terms.
It's an easy watch that nonetheless consistently feels like a grazing blow rather than a knockout.
This dumb, derivative teen slasher movie would be uninspiring coming from any writer-director, let alone one with several genre classics under his belt.
Chain Letter yields few surprises, compensating with de rigueur false scares, unmemorable deaths and the kind of improbably exaggerated gore.
Here, too much handheld camera wobble and wavering image focus only alienate the viewer from this somewhat sluggish tale.
Devil is nothing very special or original, but it gets the job done briskly and economically.
Despite the pic's assets and overall restraint, a whiff of cliched deja vu remains.
It's a pic that's akin to a terrarium of plastic flowers -- gaudily decorative, but airless and lifeless.
This is the kind of single-location indie talkfest that could translate to the stage without much tweaking. But pacing is brisk, and perfs and writing sharp enough to engage throughout.
Impressively handled sophomore feature by writer-helmer Thomasz Thompson isn't quite a slam dunk, but should beguile fans of twisty, offbeat genre fare.
Those easily moved will sniffle as cued; anyone else is likely to remain dry-eyed.
Director/co-scenarist Hugh Wilson does acceptable work here, yet the concept's myriad possibilities for satirical and fairy-tale riffing go untapped.
Delivers a formulaic-sounding conceit with enough unpredictability and downplayed sentiment to earn the heartwarming emotions that might too easily have arrived on cue.
This offbeat effort proves more admirable for its ambition than anything else, as the uneasy mix of satire, allegory, grittiness and redemption never quite jells.
Underwhelming finish explains zilch, but good perfs, atmospherics and use of backwoods locations make Yellowbrickroad an intriguing cipher.
Goldthwait's script turns into a surprisingly restrained, focused sendup of the blind adulation often bestowed on flawed personalities once they croak too soon.
It's the screenplay that ultimately demonstrates too little imagination, beyond the manner in which it bookends its predecessor.
Puppy appeal nudges past some dramatic deficiencies -- if just by a nose.
movie_title: Quill: The Life of a Guide Dog (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Agreeable if finally unsatisfying.
An indie-rock-scene satire (plus vampires) whose songlist vastly outweighs its laugh (let alone scare) quotient.
[An] entertaining docu by When We Were Kings' Leon Gast.
Crisp handling, some clever twists and a welcome streak of dry humor hold attention throughout this indie Brit thriller.

Eileen Yaghoobian's documentary presents a lot of good art and entertaining personalities in a package that's diverting on a moment-to-moment basis, but lacks any organizing principal or precise point to make the whole cohere.
Co-directors Ricki Stern and Annie Sundberg observe a year in the life of a woman who trailblazed for today's female comics and remains as driven, hard-working and career-focused as ever.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This engrossing documentary traces ugly repercussions in northern Virginia when a resolution is passed requiring cops to question anyone they have "probable cause" to suspect of being an illegal alien, a la Arizona's subsequent hot-button law.
The long and inglorious list of Bigfoot movies just got longer and more inglorious.
movie_title: Big Foot: The Lost Coast Tapes (2012)

movie_review_blurb: While the 1984 film has aged, its now-familiar jolts still pack more punch than this pic's recycled ones, which sometimes register so tepidly as to cause snickers.
Rosencrantz & Guildenstern Are Undead is one sly slice of the ridiculous.
Pacing remains flat, exacerbated by bad dialogue, some subpar f/x and variable perfs.
movie_title: The Black Waters of Echo's Pond (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Adams' fresh eye and ear, and his way with mostly non-pro thesps hold attention.
Eisner and his scenarists (Scott Kosar, Ray Wright) make changes mostly for the better, ramping up the horror factor via tighter focus on the imperiled locals and the requisite hike in gory violence.
Modest but likable effort is packaged in a straightforward style.
The offscreen story of these unknowns getting their autobiographical drama to the screen proves more interesting and inspiring than the polished, earnest, rather routine movie itself.
The Boy Who Plays on the Buddhas of Bamiyan is a fine, human-scaled portrait of an Afghanistan reeling from more than two decades of upheaval.
movie_title: The Boy Who Plays on the Buddhas of Bamiyan (2003)

movie_review_blurb: First-rate compilation Nine Nation Animation sprawls not just in terms of geography but technique, theme, style and tone, offering a filling multicourse meal for the discerning grownup toon fan.
An impartial look at U.S. military service that movingly commands respect for the personnel while requiring neither support nor assigning blame for the politics behind unpopular war efforts
Hanging out with a 1970s cult figure of raunchy R&B "party records" is less fun than one would expect in The Weird World of Blowfly.

First feature for director/co-scenarist Joel Fendelman is a middleweight drama that wears its modesty to its advantage, lending a potentially contrived tale a solid grounding in docu-style location capture and the protag's naive p.o.v.
The outstanding element in the often verite-rough package is Julien de Benedictis' editing, which organizes the potentially unwieldy mix of materials cogently, and with nary a dull moment.
movie_title: Vigilante Vigilante: The Battle for Expression (2011)

movie_review_blurb: [Offers] an interesting peek at everyday rural Afghan life in circumstances still unstable but past immediate crisis
movie_title: The Boy Mir: Ten Years in Afghanistan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A pleasant if lightweight plea for folks to quit the rat race and stop and smell the roses.
The execution falls short of its full potential.
A familiar horror/suspense trope -- criminals choose the wrong hideout, discover twisted residents more dangerous than cops -- gets entertainingly respun in The Perfect Host.
Quote not available.
The pic's creepiness factor is sufficient to rate this a notch above genre average.
Ameandering jumble that's unpleasantly vivid when portraying hunting tourism in modern-day Utah.
A cluttered, uninspired hash of familiar genre ideas.

Overblown, overlong and overstuffed with genre self-referentialism, yet undercooked in terms of credibility, worthwhile new characters and memorable scares, it's not the razor-sharp reboot fans were hoping for.
This 1970s period piece is nicely crafted and sweetly engaging overall, despite some stilted dialogue and crudely melodramatic elements.
Gripping.
A pleasant if slender affair.

Under the Boardwalk provides an amiable overview of one very famous board game's history and impact, alongside a moderately engaging portrait of players preparing for the 2009 World Monopoly Championship.
movie_title: Under The Boardwalk: The Monopoly Story (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A delightful tribute.
movie_title: Corman's World: Exploits Of A Hollywood Rebel (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There's no novelty or flair here to even briefly transcend overall predictability.
The novel premise and otherwise nuanced performances are enough to hold attention.
Chapman's sincerity is undercut by the crudely melodramatic explanations of why his principals believe as they do.
Alternately hilarious and discomfiting, and finally rather poignant.
Distinctive, frustrating and somewhat bewildering.
Assembly is brisk and high-grade, allowing for the variable quality of archival materials.
Happy Happy is a winning comedy that gets good-natured fun out of characters behaving quite badly.
Writer-director Rashaad Ernesto Green's first feature is earnest and well cast, but less involving than it should be.
Neither conventional costume drama nor abstract objet d'art, this visually ravishing, surprisingly beguiling gamble won't fit any standard arthouse niche.
Slick but instantly forgettable.
Septien proves the paths of "weird" and "interesting" do not always intersect.
First feature for Cindy Meehl is confidently assembled, with attractive contributions from the two cinematographers and composer David Robbins.
Reeder shows a knack for unsettling audiovisual textures, but once it's clear The Oregonian will offer no real storyline or explanations, viewer patience wears thin.
An infectiously fond look at a mellow moment in rock history.
Husk lacks much originality but serves up its combo plate of genre tropes with above-average flair and intensity on modest means.
This middling drama has no glaring faults, but simply lacks the intended urgency. There's scant sense of surprise in a narrative trajectory that feels preordained.
A competently handled puzzler whose derivative resolution proves its undoing.
Very entertaining docu is amusing without being condescending, touching without straining for pathos.
The wait for laughs lasts the entire length of Waiting ...
This fun dive into a bizarre creative sensibility will send viewers out combing racks for such obscure LPs as Funky Doodle and The Way Out Record for Children.
These elements leave the documentary hanging somewhere between a glorified making-of album promo and a more in-depth portrait of the artist.
[The] characters careen toward credible crises, yet the pic's numerous virtues just don't add up to a full meal.
A non-pandering crowd-pleaser whose character quirks and small stabs at poignancy feel refreshingly earned.
This technically OK but incident-free pic will induce sleep.
Quietly involving, albeit uneven.

This is the kind of movie where a madwoman's outburst leads her to throw a mug that just happens to be filled with gold sparkles -- which can then be photographed cascading down on all the adorable loonies, in slow-motion.
Playwright Phyllis Nagy's film directorial bow is an uneven affair.
For those who enjoy fashion-model-looking twentysomethings yelling at each other in bathrooms while doing too much cocaine, voila! Heaven is a place called London.
Offers nothing special in outline, but sharp performances and writing lend it a fresh appeal well above this genre's average.
Inspiration is running thin in comedian Margaret Cho's fourth concert film, a routine stand-up set that compares poorly to her oft-hilarious first two.
As boisterous as it is sobering.
Real scares are few, in part because the major characters are unsympathetic.
Sprawling from Montreal to South Africa to China, Thom Fitzgerald's 3 Needles is a great discussion tool for World AIDS Awareness Day that never achieves coherent shape as a three-paneled drama.
A charmer.
Trite and unconvincing, plastic feel-good pic is unlikely to stoke many good feelings.
The pic is amiable, kinda charming, visually routine, and incisive in individual sequences.

A comedy that doesn't build, lacks structural integrity, and often falls flat. But it's also winningly loopy, with bizarre incidental ideas and performance riffing making for a series of parts that almost make up for the faults of the whole.
What at first looks like a standard if well-crafted tour through familiar coming-of-age territory takes some interesting detours.
An alarming if ultimately inspiring David-and-Goliath parable for today.
Sticking fairly close to the 2001 novel, co-scenarists Delia Ephron and Elizabeth Chandler preserve its strengths as a complex adolescent soap operasoap opera leavened by humor, warmth and empathy.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Pleasant, if mediocre family fare.
Gordon's nifty scenario juggles various aspects -- ordinary brink-of-adolescence growing pains, multicultural-tolerance lessons, suspense gambits -- with entertaining skill.
[An] offbeat but engrossing package.
movie_title: Casuistry: The Art of Killing a Cat (2005)

movie_review_blurb: This strenuous zombie yukfest is no more sophisticated than its nail-on-head title -- making it a joke no smarter than the movies it riffs on.
A so-so attempt to wring a personal documentary from a 10-year-old news story.
Deftly balances elements of pathos, humor and the grotesque while maintaining a low-key tenor.
Helmer's own script feels unfocused and semi-improvisational, with good ideas that should've been taken further, and some not-so-good ones that overstay their welcome.
Within the terms of broad, even crude comedy the pic sets for itself, Eating Out is funny more often than not, hilarious on occasion.
[A] richly atmospheric exercise in surreal horror.

The movie sometimes grows precarious from the weight of too many crises and hairpin turns from comedy to drama. But both script and direction are ultimately up to the task, trumping occasional improbability with sharp observation.
Pic's degree of access and intimacy is surprising, even more so when closing intertitles reveal Chinese authorities did try to shut down the filmmakers several times.
Comedian Margaret Cho calls her first non-concert feature as writer-star "a fag and fag-hag 'Thelma and Louise,'" a description that's funnier than anything in Bam Bam and Celeste.
A long, structureless muddle that does justice to neither the stellar acts nor changing countercultural times event has encompassed.

Despite intriguingly stark aesthetic and moderate suspense, however, Roger Ingraham's feature doesn't deliver quite enough character depth, plot twists or satisfying mayhem to seem more than an OK idea just half-developed.
Input from historians and surviving intimates, archival material and handsome latter-day footage retracing Choepel's journeys mix smoothly in polished package.
[A] diverting but ultimately weightless effort.
[The film] finds more than enough absorbing material to hold interest through nearly three-hour runtime.
Assured handling and an appealing cast make this a deserving crowd-pleaser.
An excellent educational tool.
Droll tale is plainly mounted, but perfs, situations and Ash Gibson Grieg's quirky original score hold attention.
In leading players' righteousness and unwillingness to compromise, this real-life drama encapsulates current U.S. society's tug-of-war over values.
movie_title: Clear Cut: The Story of Philomath, Oregon (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An unusually low-key Filipino drama whose neo-realist air generally triumphs over the script's violent, tearful contrivances.
Son of Man boils down the life of Jesus Christ to 86 concise minutes, restoring layers of political motivation largely absent from The Passion of the Christ and adding stirring original vocal music.
Sports too many formulaic weaknesses of mainstream laffers while straining for an indie cred that hitherto came naturally to writer-director Finn Taylor.
An excellent overview of the ambiance and showcased talent at arguably the best annual U.S. rock festival ...
A terrific performance by Ryan GoslingRyan Gosling is the chief but hardly sole reason to embrace Half Nelson.
Gyllenhaal, in her most substantial role since Secretary, does a fine, unshowy job of limning Sherry's faults without alienating the viewer or pleading for sympathy.
Deftly sustaining many points of view, engrossing feature begins to seem overloaded only toward the end.
A trite, whitewashed-to-blankness vanity project.
movie_title: Everyone Stares: The Police Inside Out (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Susan Kaplan's (Small Wonders) first feature as director is tightly told, with a production sheen that's above-average for fly-on-the-wall documentary.
movie_title: Three of Hearts: A Postmodern Family (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Black & white almost always looks good - - the one lesson learned by viewers of Frankenstein vs. the Creature From Blood Cove, a campy quasi-horror flashback sorely lacking in satiric oomph.
movie_title: Frankenstein vs. the Creature from Blood Cove (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The film's edge gets softer as it goes - - in ways that might baffle all but the granola-scarfing well-heeled hippies it seemed to be parodying.
Pic is particularly well-crafted, managing to avoid the ambulance-chasing tenor that might easily have turned this into a voyeuristic freakshow.
Unpolished, sometimes gratuitously first-person account nonetheless carries considerable punch as an on-the-street look at how Iraqis view their 'liberation' and liberators.
The film's insistence he's the Next Big Thing is perhaps a tad too much, too soon.
[It's] scary cinema pushed to the brink of punishment. But there's no question that what it sets out to do, it does alarmingly well.
Dani Menkin's documentary tracks his odyssey, which by nature is hard to be cynical about. Still, the feature feels padded even at 70 minutes.
Naked in Ashes is a respectful, illuminating appreciation of a few of the estimated 13 million yogis in India.
Engrossing.
An excellent overview of two decades' graffiti in San Francisco.
Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing & Charm School juggles three separate time periods -- and is completely formulaic in each one.
movie_title: Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing & Charm School (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Personalities are as engaging as they are diverse, while zippy, well-photographed package is never dull.
Somebodies adds up to little more than a series of uninspired skits untethered to any thematic or narrative substance.
Trivial-sounding hook manages to float a funny but complex meditation on identity, ethnicity and cultural expectations that should be as accessible to teens as adults.
[This] sharp survey brings an insular, now largely forgotten scene back to vivid life.
Too many visual gimmicks and a cast overburdened with big names in small roles soften Victoria Redel's acclaimed debut novel.
A powerful and damning look at the long-term impact of sexual abuse, as well as the less-than-exemplary response of Catholic Church officials to allegations of priestly molestation.
First-rate talent and a uniquely dyspeptic mood separate this effort from more routine, populist stabs at tasteless yukkage.
A genial comedy.

This H.K./U.S. co-production at times plays as if it were aimed at children, but more often simply seems to be aiming blind at whatever genre cliche the five credited writers fix upon in any given scene.
A riveting troubled teens story that has the unvarnished poignance of first-rank docus (e.g. Streetwise, Decline of Western Civilization III, etc.) on similar thematic turf.
Often hilarious and always diverting.
Controversial fine-arts photographer Shelby Lee Adams is given a fascinatingly even-handed cinematic trial.
movie_title: The True Meaning of Pictures: Shelby Lee Adams' Appalachia (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Not only was this one of the [Sundance] festival's strongest nonfiction titles, but its message deserves a much wider airing than skittish broadcasters are likely to allow.
Performances don't benefit from the picture's uncertain tone, which wavers between quasi-hardboiled 'black' comedy and guilt-tripping sentimentality.
Noisy, grating and morally dubious.
This year's kinder, gentler Animal House.
A colorful, lurid and ultimately so-what look at some rather obnoxious personalities careening down their little road to ruin.

This adaptation of LaBute's 2001 play provides a queasy investigation of male-female relations that ends with a satisfying shudder of recognition at the extreme cruelty possible within human relationships, particularly those conceived by Neil LaBute.
The slapstick is labored, and the bigger setpieces flat.
An unsophisticated sci-fi drama that takes itself all too seriously.
Always watchable yet ultimately self-defeating in terms of its tonal / aesthetic choices.

A thoughtful and ingratiating seriocomedy, Vancouverite Ori Kowarsky's first feature "Various Positions" goes awry in the last half-hour, as script's intended cathartic explosions go off with a whimper.
Originality ain't on the menu, but there's never a dull moment in the giant spider invasion comic chiller.
[Brings] absolutely no fresh angles to a time-tested formula that's seemed particularly overworked of late.
Initially buoyant and flavorful, pic grows less distinctive as Jung's rise-and-fall saga hits the downhill slope.
The guy can't control his 'monkey,' get it? Heh-heh. Yep, that's the whole concept. Heh. Pretty twisted, eh? Heh ... har ... um ... zzzzzz.
A feel-good comic ensembler that's hard to resist.
Looking good but lacking much in the way of personality or gray matter.
Even formula-slasher-pic fans are likely to find this hectic, unfocused effort a letdown.
Fitfully amusing!
Myers and Michael McCullers' script just doesn't have it in terms of fresh narrative developments or individual gags.
movie_title: Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me (1999)

movie_review_blurb: The signature zaniness is missing from director Michael Corrente's adaptation.
Warchus' accomplished handling and the stars' flavorful performances lend Simpatico a bittersweet grace.
A more clever diversion than anyone had any right to expect!
A pat, hollow exercise!
Entertaining but never fully engrossing.
A jumbled fantasy comedy that did not figure out a coherent game plan at scripting, shooting or post-production stages.
That it took Griffin and three (credited) collaborators to come up with a script this by-numbers only proves once again that too many cooks homogenize the soup.
A potent, engrossing look at several young refugees from Sudan's disastrous, endless civil war who've been relocated to the U.S.
Results comprise a potent and discomfiting document that will trigger strong reactions.
An exercise in bad taste that takes itself just seriously enough to be offensive.
Perhaps the strangest element here isn't the narrative conceit itself, but the fact that director Munch handles it in such typically low-key, benevolently observant fashion.
Pic's nastiness is so insistent, one-dimensional and excessive it risks self-parody.
Appealing as both nature docu and character study.
movie_title: The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Overall tenor amplifies Kumbh Mela's own atmosphere of tolerance, generosity, and earnest spiritual questing.
movie_title: Short Cut to Nirvana: Kumbh Mela (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Blade: Trinity won't linger in the memory long, but gives pretty good action eye-candy while it's going.
Its own mythology aside, this flamboyant, graphic and disturbing quasi-docu reenactment of a notorious chapter in U.S. counterculture life is a fascinating if peculiar accomplishment.

Beyond the lure of going intimately behind the scenes with two excellent indie outfits (one drastically underappreciated), DIG! offers fascinating insights into how some vivid personalities fare in the music industry.
Getting so close to real-life mental illness, via footage that spans many years, renders Tarnation a uniquely potent experience.
Despite its shortcomings, Primer remains watchable thanks to Carruth's dense and intriguing filmmaking.
There are cheaply effective if unoriginal scares. Filmmakers bring a certain verve to such moments; but building atmosphere and suspense is well beyond them. Ditto handling actors.
Solid, straightforward docu should prove a durable broadcast and educational item for years to come.
A rough-hewn but sometimes very funny sort of performance diary.
It comes off as forced wackiness of the worst kind, at once cloddish and faux-sophisticated.
A lively, plush but unconvincing potboiler cobbled from familiar pieces of better films.
This tale of tortured love between a gay youth and street hustler juggles a complex load of emotional and tonal colors within an admirably lean runtime.
An unstable -- if mostly painless -- mix of low comedy, stabs at higher silliness, and schmaltz.
As actor, helmer and co-scenarist (with Dennis Haggerty), Mario ultimately delivers a tale that's engrossing for its underdog quality and significant place in film history.

While not the all-encompassing, hard-facts indictment Fast Food Nation readers might hope for, this more entertainment-oriented package does throw in enough disturbing figures and informative side trips to provide an educational-value meal.
A cheerfully silly ode to larger-than-life femininity.
Characters are well-drawn, perfs persuasive, sum effect quietly touching.

Potent docu by Katy Chevigny and Kirsten Johnson makes a strong case against capital punishment by pointing up the fallibility of the justice system, while offering an inspiring portrait of one politico who actually seems guided foremost by conscience.
Scabrous video art teetering between falutin' gallery and lowdown carnal imagery.
movie_title: Georges Bataille's Story of the Eye (2004)

movie_review_blurb: There's a slightness to the mildly eccentric material here that leaves the whole enterprise in danger of fluttering away.

No matter one's party affiliation, docu is worth seeing for its eye-opening look at how disreputable characters can impact government -- and how easily the mainstream media can be duped into covering scandal-smelling leads.
One needn't be a fan of Metallica or heavy metal to be engrossed throughout.
Docu's case-pleading is duly high-minded and effective. But the sense of emotional identification that might have really socked the point across is lacking.
Script doesn't sufficiently fill in the blanks left by historical record regarding the personalities involved, which robs the central relationship of emotional (let alone tragic) depth.
Competent but innocuous feature begins to overstay welcome at the 60-minute mark.
Goes beyond simple Bush-bashing to paint a horrifying portrait of organized U.S. imperialist expansion and public deception stretching back to the early Reagan era.
Going from the noisily routine to the ludicrous, AVP's final reel or so are likely to produce howls.
A surprisingly cogent, entertaining, even rabble-rousing indictment of perhaps the most influential institutional model for our era.
The family adventure Eight Below is an easy watch, thanks to the splendors of frosty scenery and furry canines.
An impressive declaration of talent that nonetheless gets a little drunk and disorderly at the trough of High Art.
Another unpredictable left turn in story and stylistic terrain for helmer Toshiaki Toyoda.
A striking study of madness that skirts horror territory.
It's remarkable to what extent Aronofsky has rendered the cerebral kinetically intense. The film's imaginative, diverse images create a mind's-eye urban claustrophobia.
