Tales are dramatic; the interviewees poignant, and the images -- often following bodies all the way down to the water -- are startling and discomfiting.
As adulatory as a testimonial dinner, pic looks at talents well deserving of more complex, balanced treatment.
This tale of a pregnant small-town woman caught between a bad marriage and a risky affair is mostly as funny and charming as intended.
An inauspicious feature debut for director Harv Glazer and all three scenarists, the Big-meets-breakdancing comedy will be kickin' it to ancillary by swimsuit season.

Pic could use more humor, though it does have scattered unintentional laughs, particularly one late, solemnly admonishing speech about how those producing entertainment need to take responsibility for glorifying violence.
Though slick and diverting in some aspects, increasingly silly pic has trouble meshing disparate elements -- horror, superhero fantasy, straight-up action -- into a workable whole.
X-Men plays like a so-so middle chapter of an epic series rather than a fitting kickoff.
This feature-length expansion offers a diverting package of surreal, rude stoner- and pop culture-based humor that will delight youthful viewers while bewildering stray elders.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Uninspired staging and pacing manage the near-impossible feat of rendering such lunatic concepts dull.
movie_title: The Glamorous Life of Sachiko Hanai (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Package is lively, if loosely structured.
Thing suffers the familiar curse of Canadian seriocomedy -- just nice enough in content and stylistically like a telepic.
Tale of a 30ish quartet at personal crossroads in the wealthy, idyllic Santa Monica Mountains sports juicy conflicts and prickly dialogue, though the directorial approach remains judiciously low-key.
As endearing as it is amusing.
movie_title: Monster Camp: The Story of NERO Seattle (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If Lee intended primarily to spoof documentary conventions, she should have chosen a theme less commercially overexposed -- and worked harder at making it more than just sorta-kinda humorous.
Jokes are hit-and-miss, but they splat target often enough to make this a guilty pleasure that homophile fans of both Napoleon Dynamite and American Pie might enjoy.
Those who've wondered whether TV's WWF show wrestling might have a detrimental effect on impressionable youth will gloat over The Backyard.
A compelling mix of archival materials and latter-day testimony.
Stronger style and atmosphere would have greatly benefited a pic that seems to abandon its own supernatural aspects to sheer plot mechanism.
Rolling does communicate some positive aspects of Ecstasy, its ability to break down emotional barriers and induce unfettered positive communication.
Focusing on a bisexual pretty-white-boy hustler and his older black sometime partner during a couple of consequentially chaotic days, this verite-style drama has the ring of lived-in truth.
Uninspired script and broad slapstick yuks won't earn this any plaudits, but slick, safe package should do OK with North American mall auds.
Eerie frights here are more a matter of sheer dread-soaked atmosphere.
A well-produced but slow-moving thriller that never quite roars to life.
Pic's aggressively trendy, empty early progress suggests Go shrunk to fit the brainpan of a Paris Hilton universe.
A conventional but nicely handled slasher pic that makes good use of spectacular mountain range locations.
An intriguing subject let down by an aimless structure and lack of distanced perspective.
movie_title: Children of God: Lost and Found (2007)

movie_review_blurb: After an hour of entertainingly crass buildup, pic erupts in a riot of outrageous, quite funny violence that leaves almost no one alive. Punk/metal soundtrack is in keeping with gonzo tone.
An exercise in canned cuteness.
Pic has built up enough goodwill to keep auds stoked to the end.

It's one of the best Broadway-tuner adaptations in recent years -- yes, arguably even better than those Oscar-winning ones. Unpretentious, feel-good pic is low on histrionic diva wailing and MTV-style editing, high on retro movie-musical craftsmanship.
The semi-earnest A Four Letter Word comes off like an insular gay sitcom, a la Paul Rudnick's Jeffrey, but without the honed verbal wit.
A scattershot stab at a fascinating life and times.
Horror fans who value credible creepiness over the usual splatdom will welcome this.
Undeniably entertaining for its zippy presentation.
The Wackness treads this familiar terrain with assurance and distinction.
Quietly involving pic.
movie_title: Alone in Four Walls (Allein in Veir W√§nden) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Decent if derivative.
Debuting writer-director Joby Harold's thriller does have an attention-getting plot hook, but piles on too many narrative gimmicks to maintain suspense or credibility.
A stranger-than-truth tale both amusing and appalling...
Pedestrian handling, a clumsy script and some poor acting from name and local thesps alike squander the story's potential.
Beneath late-night cable standards.
Action is almost nonstop, but rooting interest palls.
All wet but none too scary.
Deftly balances humor and insight.
Force of personality and terrific vintage performance clips make a keeper of Anita O'Day: The Life of a Jazz Singer.
movie_title: Anita O'Day: The Life of a Jazz Singer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Result is a mixed bag but has a catchy premise and quite enough splatter to satisfy gorehounds.
Only Henry Winkler as Ben's carpet-salesman pa has the joie de vivre the pic desperately needs.

Cooper presented this rather basic good/evil mythos in more low-key, atmospheric form than the film allows, leaving thesps (particularly McShane) having to poker-face their way through lines like, 'The future of the human race rests on you!'
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Keeps most cliches at bay.
A slick but forgettable, characterless thriller.
Boll does mean to provoke, but to pull off a satirical critique of the volatile subjects here would require sharper wit than he and co-scenarist Bryan C. Knight generally provide.
Despite natural perfs, characters aren't very articulate or well-defined.
Overlapping with other recent docus, pic nonetheless presents a stimulating argument.
The best that can be said about Rob Zombie's Halloween remake is that he makes it his own, though the considerable alterations only flatter John Carpenter's 1978 slasher-pic template.
Sean Penn delivers a compelling, ambitious work that will satisfy most admirers of the book.
Pic's self-serving approach is contemptible.
Cast is first-rate all around, unafraid to play up the annoying, insensitive or self-pitying aspects of their nonetheless likeable characters.

Effectively mixing original broadcast and amateur vid footage (especially during scenes of crowd panic and police brutality) with interwoven fictive strands, Townsend acquits himself well, if not outstandingly, as both writing and directing newbie.
Visceral and engrossing.
The undernourished story penned by thesp-turned-scenarist Jackson isn't scary, eventful or enigmatic enough to seem worth the bother.
Dumb sensationalism that trusts blood-buckets dumped on thesps are enough to raise a fright.
Writer-helmer Bruce Sweeney can't decide if the lead figure is a comic caricature or pathetic mental case; his resolution is so desultory it feels like he ceased caring.

Beyond capturing some impressive musicianship (notably from innovative drummer Brian Blade), this deliberately low-grade presentation is a chore to watch, unalleviated by solarized-color bits and gratuitous dance interludes.
There are no surprises here -- just broad, frequently slapstick gags that don't avoid but do tamp down a bit on the bodily-function school of yokkery.
Film's sobering impact lets the images and witnesses' words speak for themselves.
movie_title: White Light/Black Rain: The Destruction of Hiroshima and Nagasaki (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Like its shy hero, Four Sheets to the Wind is so low-key it risks making little impression -- until you realize it (and he) has stealthily won viewer sympathy and affection.
Ponderous drama is one part well-shot docu capturing hurricane destruction and survivor testimony to two parts fictive bore with annoying characters embroiled in underdeveloped conflicts.
These five stories set in post-Milosevic Serbia are unrelated beyond their general air of disillusionment, providing little satisfaction individually or as a whole.
It feels very familiar in conceit and unadventurous in execution, but offers the undeniable pleasures of a well-observed, well-played modest seriocomedy.
For all their surface bluster, debuting co-writers/directors Jon Schroder and Randall K. Rubin are trading in reflexive sulky adolescent philosophy.
Brightly packaged and steadily amusing, even if the script never really develops anything interesting from its high-concept premise.
A gracefully wrought study of a long-term marriage being wedged apart by Alzheimer's.

Delightful docu A Cantor's Tale casts a fond eye back at the 'golden age' of chazzanut (Jewish liturgical music) and its star performers in the Brooklyn of yesteryear, while also profiling one of the form's most significant latter-day advocates.

Brown's screenplay and direction, both economical and unshowy, sketch character dynamics in crisp terms that resist the temptation to explain all, beg sympathy or heighten drama for purely histrionic purposes.
Overall story arc is fairly predictable, and deliberate pacing sometimes risks dullness.
Most of the time, the personalities are so engaging that the viewer is just pleased to share their company, on or off-stage.
Amerindie Colma: The Musical just gives the kids music they like and characters they can identify with, forgetting any grandiosity.
Amnesia: The James Brighton Enigma ekes middling results from a fascinating storyline.
Blandly earnest drama of a young gay man trying to raise his little brother after they're orphaned plays like an After-School Special...
Uneven but generally effective drama has his teenage protag at a crossroads between street life and the straight-and-narrow.

Providing an inspiration for active retirement, the ex-Harlem Renaissance chorus girls profiled in docu Been Rich All My Life are still shaking booty while most of their contemporaries can only shuffle their walkers.
Treasures offers nonstop aesthetic stimulation. Nonetheless, the focus is awkwardly split, and the central figure isn't probed in any psychological depth.
Story (which sports some narrative gaps and underdeveloped subplots) turns tear-jerkingly tragic, in pointed, rather ham-fisted fashion.

Inspired jokes run neck-and-neck with flat ones. Still, the faux 'instructive' tone (full of ostensible life lessons that couldn't be more amoral) and rack of offbeat characterizations keeps things diverting.
Unjustly overlooked at Sundance by both auds and jurors, Mark Becker's Romantico is a beautifully lensed -- on actual film -- docu about illegal Mexican immigrants.

There is an undeniable quirky appeal to the creative world of Daniel Smith, though those who hope a behind-the-scenes look will explain his motivation or personality won't find the enigma resolved here.

Tale of a high-school rowing team's captain going through major changes during a week-long training retreat is routine in some aspects, but compensates via psychologically sharp writing and performances.
This diverting, occasionally wry seriocomedy ultimately doesn't add up to a satisfying whole.
Those hoping for either a sizzling -- or an unintentionally hilarious -- good time will be disappointed by this inexplicably dull sequel.
Hand-wringing approach lacks dignity and naturalism, instead trusting that more crying scenes mean more emotional impact.
Despite patina of political commentary, pic's shrill supporting stereotypes and sloppy narrative/tech assembly dominate.
[A] straightforward, engrossing documentary about a well-buried chapter in recent evangelical history.
movie_title: Frisbee: The Life and Death of a Hippie Preacher (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Withholding basic expository material, and unpredictably restless in its focus, Innocence both rivets and challenges emotional engagement.
Anyone unfamiliar with the book's basic ideas will probably choke on their popcorn, agog at so much windy spiritual mumbo-jumbo floating in a woozy stew of action-adventure absurdity.
There's a straight-ahead confidence to this smoothly packaged pic that overcomes most of the flaws.
In the end, Silent Hill degenerates into an overblown replay of all those Twilight Zone and Stephen King stories in which outsiders stumble upon a time-warped location from which there's no escape.
An uneven, occasionally vivid, ultimately unsatisfactory treatment of themes that should've packed more punch.
A by-the-numbers ensemble dramedy that hits every underdog and gay-fish- out-of-water cliche on the nose.

The even numbers don't favor the Scary Movie franchise. Inspiration ran dry for the Wayans Brothers in No. 2; now successors David Zucker & Co suffer gag fatigue following up their moderately improving efforts on the third installment.
As ever, those willing to go with the flow will experience something beautiful and hypnotic; others will quickly find the exit.
For all its appealing performances and persuasive individual scenes, The Bubble makes an uneven impression.
Deep-dyed deadpan Monkey Warfare reps an above-average entry in the Canadian cinematic tradition of loser comedy.
An accomplished character piece that sustains interest in a conceit nearly as slender as its protagonist.
Pic's charm seems so offhand one might not notice the skill with which helmer John Carney pulls it off, or how it plays like a full-blown musical without anyone bursting into song.
In order to play John Lennon's assassin Mark David Chapman, actor Jared Leto gained some 70 pounds. Seemingly following his lead, the pic itself is heavy, lethargic, and exasperating.
A delicate piece with good performances and an intriguing enough setup, the drama ultimately doesn't go anywhere definite or distinctive enough to leave a lasting impression.
In Faris, pic has a comedienne with the ability to wring endless variations on a limited theme (the 'I'm-so-baked' one) and she pretty much single-handedly compensates for anything lacking.
A fascinating subject handled with intelligently provocative care.
The sheer fascinating strangeness of the people documented could earn the pic a minor cult following.
Clubland is warm and entertaining enough, with Brenda Blethyn doing a variation on her Little Voice vulgarian amid appealing support perfs.
Uneven but often hilarious. Bad-taste quotient is cranked up here, ditto the overall conceptual giddiness.
Steve Buscemi's adaptation preserves the original's biting basic scenario while adding a few Americanizing tweaks to this tale.
Methodically relating the story -- as told by several of the U.S. soldiers involved -- whose leak to the media badly damaged U.S. credibility, Ghosts of Abu Ghraib makes grim but worthwhile viewing.
There's more than enough intelligence, intrigue and performance dazzle to make this an adventuresome gizmo for grownups.

Though there's little unfamiliar here, pic's tipping the scales more toward latent-depression drama and away from typical romcom situation gags (the humor here is more offhand) makes it seem truer to life than many similar exercises.

Director Michael Katleman, making his bigscreen debut after a couple decades' TV work, keeps the pacing tight, the acting straight-faced and the laughs mostly intentional (though Jones' one-liners occasionally fall flat).
The four-years-in-the-making, badly recycled (not to mention awful) sequel might stain the honor of the Lampoon label if it hadn't already produced several even worse films.
movie_title: Van Wilder: The Rise of Taj (Van Wilder 2) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: More icky than scary, with a rather obnoxious Ugly American as lead protagonist.
It's impossible not to admire the protags' can-do spirit.
Impressionistic docu Kurt Cobain: About a Son is a counterpoint to the iconic late Nirvana rocker's legacy.
This convoluted, arbitrary, overlong whimsy will strike most grown-ups as childish, and is far too violent and pretentious for kids.
Basically throwing together familiar horror ideas without focusing on any in particular, Feast hopes its wild tone will compensate for the lack of distinctive characters or ideas.
An imperfect but compelling thriller.
An effectively harrowing and non-exploitative recap of real-life events.
As lovingly crafted as it is unsettlingly sour-sweet.

Pairing cult directors with macabre omnibus material is always a tasty proposition, but the results disappoint in Trapped Ashes, a quartet of mildly sexed-up, unscary horror tales with a unifying wraparound story.
Pic's retro feel is rendered pleasing overall by scribe's linguistic flair and the enjoyable cast.

Pic insists on a depth of human emotion that isn't developed -- protags emerge as one-dimensional, despite the efforts of two of our best leading actors -- amid increasingly elaborate, uninvolving plot mechanizations.

A successful mix of scripted drama with on-location improv, and a rare instance of U.S. narrative cinema that engages the politics of the moment, Mora Stephens' Conventioneers refreshes on several levels.
An amusing send-up of late '50s/early '60s high-school melodramas and teen-tragedy pop hits.
Time-killer chiller reps an undistinguished U.S. debut for U.K. helmer Asif Kapadia, though the undernourished script may be most at fault.
Let's Go to Prison feels like an overextended sketch-comedy idea insufficiently filled out by subsidiary characters (few significantly figure) or standout setpieces.
A poorly crafted grab-bag of ideas barely elaborated upon enough to sustain a 20-minute short.
Provides a serviceable if uninspired companion piece to The Celluloid Closet and other overviews of minority (mis-)representation.
A cheaper, cheesier sequel that's worse than its predecessor on every level (save being a half-hour shorter) and takes no special advantage of the stereoscopic process.
"A Little Chaos" is all too tidy as it imposes a predictable, pat modern sensibility on a most unconvincing depiction of late 17th-century French aristocratic life ...
A gruesome but uninspired environmental-disaster thriller that's an unconvincing example of the overexposed faux-found-footage horror subgenre.
This ludicrous costume shoot-'em-up only inflates its whopping clich√©s and anachronisms by placing them in the incongruously deployed IMAX format.
Wilson delivers a hardworking performance that nonetheless can't render a familiar character type fascinating enough in a vacuum, with so little support in the writing.
movie_title: I Am the Pretty Thing That Lives in the House (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Ovredal's first English-langauge feature makes good on the promise of his homegrown 2011 fantasy action hit "Trollhunter."
Fans of extreme Asian genre action won't care that things eventually grow somewhat predictable and repetitive: In terms of sheer, punchy physical vigor, "Headshot" is a knockout.
Never rises above polished plastic, formulaic, and pedestrian.

There's not much beyond pretty scenery and forced "grittiness" to distract from the hollow histrionics at the heart of "Strange Weather," whose clumsy signifiers include being set during a long, hot drought.
Gracelessly mashes together hardboiled crime-melodrama cliches and an unintentionally funny "Oh no! I'm a chick now!!" gender-change narrative hook.
As a self-aware guilty pleasure, "The Belko Experiment" may not quite seize greatness, but it does give it a playful squeeze.
As busy and artificial as Victorian interior decor at its most excessive, "The Limehouse Golem" is similarly rather too much of a posh good thing.
[An] assured suspense drama, which sports little of the blackly comedic streak usually associated with its maker ...
This is awfully soft stuff, its navel-gazing protagonist not nearly as unusual or delightful as we're meant to think despite the high IQ she can't stop referencing.
Though its marquee names and trenchant social satire will prove most potent on home turf, "I Am Not Madame Bovary's" often sublimely ridiculously progress ...
Though its take-away impact may be flimsy, "Level Up" does suggest that Randall ... has the facility and confidence to handle more substantial material, as well as a bigger budget.
"Vengeance" is well-crafted good fun - and good proof that you don't need more than two hours or $100 million to give ticket buyers their money's worth in popcorn thrills.
The fascination of puzzling out a compulsive fire-setter's motivations keeps "Pyromaniac" absorbing, even if the film itself provides precious few answers in that regard.
A drolly amusing, lightly macabre variation on the standard lesbian romantic comedy.
If there isn't much subtlety or surprise in Yeung's screenplay, his direction is graceful enough to make this a pleasant if unmemorable bittersweet love story.
Glossy, colorful, and forgettable, "Skiptrace" is the kind of movie that gives you your money's worth in sheer eager-to-please entertainment even as you roll eyes at the nth kick-to-the-crotch gag.
It's a lovingly crafted ode to little-loved cinema that's secure enough in its obscurantist nostalgia to make a sly joke of its occasional anachronisms ...
Diverting if seldom hilarious.
While "The Alchemist Cookbook" certainly won't be for everyone, it will surely delight and surprise those who can grok its idiosyncratic content.
Doesn't plumb deep or long enough among these lives to achieve the full inspirational impact it's aiming for.
This slender documentary's surprising disinterest in exploring related larger topics ultimately makes for a very superficial treatment of its subject.

This autobiographically inspired tale of a wealthy Jewish family in Tehran suffering under Iran's shift to fundamentalist Islam, which played in print as hard-hitting but nuanced, now feels like a simplistic, somewhat pandering melodrama.

Incorporating archival footage dating back several decades alongside its predominant v√©rit√© observations and concert footage, "Kingdom" is juicy without being disrespectful, the backstage dramas ultimately secondary to the thrill of the music itself.
movie_title: The Wonderful Kingdom of Papa Alaev (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An awkwardly revealing act of subversion that is arresting however you take it: as propaganda deconstructed, failed or turned into a tragicomedy whose most stinging indictments lie mostly in what remains unseen.
This fun if unmemorable occult thriller sports - all too faithfully at times - both the typical pleasures and shortcomings of the movies it pays homage to.
It's a sweet movie - just not not wholly a "documentary" to whose reality you'd necessarily trust your own grandmother when depositing her at the rest home.
movie_title: My Love, Don't Cross That River (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Auberjonois' polished feature debut provides an impressive showcase for co-scenarist Kate Nowlin as a career Marine derailed by PTSD upon return to civilian life.
Traitel, a first-time actor whose own background seems all too eerily apt for this character, is riveting in a demanding role with little dialogue or psychological explication to lean on.
A nicely crafted if not entirely satisfying drama of a man struggling to retain any connection to human society.
Another significant chapter in Polish history from Wajda, albeit one unlikely to travel as widely as some of his past subjects.

"Colossal" takes diminishing advantage of an amusing premise, one that seems made for satirical treatment yet is executed with an increasingly awkward semi-seriousness the characters aren't depthed (or likable) enough to ballast.
An astute mixture of multi-strand drama and murder mystery that engrosses for two solid hours.
Wherever adults talk to kids about "making a difference," this documentary should be shown.

The occasional heavy-handed or clumsy elements don't seriously impair a film whose high spirits, talented cast and luridly intriguing subject consistently entertain, even if they seldom truly surprise.

Manages to develop its own distinct flavor while fitting snugly into the general tradition of latter-day U.K. gangster pics, with their rueful humor, colorful characters and realistically nasty violence.
Its up-close portrait of heroic dedication in extreme situations has the dramatic immediacy and air of privileged access to impress both hawks and doves.

Impressive aerial shots of scenic splendors, as well as Tom Brokaw's narration - that voice now a sort of craggy edifice in itself - tie together this episodic feature into a polished and entertaining if conventional whole.
"Dolores" crams a great deal of information, themes, and diverse archival materials into a sharp, cogent whole ...
Consistently involving, with content diverse enough to avoid the tunnel-visioned pitfalls of diarist cinema.
An ingratiating comedy based on an improbable true story.
Nostalgia is one thing, but Defa's feature itself is an example of reprising things about the past that didn't particularly work.
Though "The Discovery" starts out with a great premise, its mystery dissipates over a somewhat tepid course as the concept ultimately heads in a direction we've seen many times before ...
Transcends the cliches even as the film uses plenty of familiar tropes, laying down a solid hour of effective buildup to a duly hair-raising, prolonged climax.
Vividly conveys the siege atmosphere that can trigger reckless, "retaliatory" violence.
What might have easily become a familiar if worthy exercise in peasant miserabilism acquires an otherworldly quality via arresting imagery and enigmatic, fragmented storytelling.
An engrossing, ultimately poignant chronicle ...
movie_title: Eagles of Death Metal: Nos Amis (Our Friends) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Brandt impressively limns a character whose intelligence and complexity are always evident, along with a sometimes dislikable brittleness.
Leading Israeli choreographer Ohad Naharin is profiled in Mr. Gaga, possibly the most exciting documentary for fans of edgier modern dance since Pina.
movie_title: Mr. Gaga: A True Story of Love and Dance (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Not all of it works, but this is a bold and talented debut, all the more impressive for transcending (while embracing) some shameless exploitation tropes.
A most auspicious debut.
Arguably less scary than "Big Top Pee-Wee."
A shadowy organization that kept the hippies dosed at the height of the '60s counterculture is brought to the light of day in this entertaining documentary.
While hardly the first and unlikely to be the last cinematic word on its subject, this finely crafted docu may well long stand as the most balanced among such treatments.
Though the film eventually grows as repetitious as its subject's habit, this odd tale has an undeniable bizarro human-interest fascination.
An admirably lean-and-mean execution of an elemental horror story.
Irene Taylor Brodsky's documentary is mostly a straightforward, inevitably engrossing true-crime tale.
Competently crafted but uninspired ...
A franchise-aspirational horror opus that takes too long establishing its premise, then peters out in a climactic jumble of scare-free digital effects.
Sturm draws on a rich array of material to assemble a first documentary feature that's fascinating on numerous levels.
Polished without ever achieving much in the realm of suspense or emotional involvement.

Marson's lively narrative employs a lot of diverse voices as well as a surprising amount of archival footage in telling a story that's ethically complex yet easy to follow. All tech and design contributions are nicely turned.
The combination of raves, hallucinogens, wild youth, and pagan rituals in a creepy former mental asylum ought to add up to something a lot more exciting than "City of Dead Men."

[Its] sheer good-naturedness pulls off a not particularly inspired crusty-old-coot-thawed-by-young-scamp concept, maintaining an agreeable tonal balance despite occasional wobbles between spoof, sentimentality and silliness.
An energetic and entertaining exercise that could spawn its own spin-offs.

This slick, entertaining portrait won't provide many surprises for those who've followed the subject's high-profile career - as pretty much anyone interested in surfing has - but should fascinate others for whom he's a less familiar personality.
movie_title: Take Every Wave: The Life of Laird Hamilton (2017)

movie_review_blurb: [A] highly entertaining stranger-than-fiction saga.
Cruz's ample star appeal buoys this flimsy vehicle to a point, but even that quality isn't infallible.
In stylistic terms, however, The Similars is fully realized as a semi-camp yet canny homage to vintage suspense templates.
The narrative spine that might have given this version an arc and a purpose fails to materialize.
You'd have to be immune to canine charm not to be sufficiently entertained by the antics of the lucky dogs Dennett gives major screentime to.
The 'Blair Witch' comparisons don't flatter this derivative horror indie.
A mildly mentally disabled young woman strains for independence in this well-crafted drama.
This arresting seriocomedy deftly walks a tightrope between droll and tense, over a gaping pit of crazy.
Elegantly crafted yet neither convincing nor stylized enough to pull off its rather theatrical conceit.
This entertaining-enough quartet of loosely interwoven terror tales falls right into the middle ground of horror omnibuses, with no outright duds but no truly memorable (or scary) segments either.
Beguiling ...
The overall result is not exactly dull, but given the talent and potential here, should have been more poignant and memorable.
The famed African-American poet and memoirist is profiled in this solid if conventional docu.
movie_title: Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A clever Dutch family comedy.
Eat That Question: Frank Zappa In His Own Words pulls together interview, concert and behind-the-scenes footage to commemorate one of the rock era's most idiosyncratic star musicians.
movie_title: Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A sleeper delight.
A competent but unmemorable B-movie that eschews any real political content in favor of simple, brutal survival melodrama with scant room for surprises in plot, character or directorial style.
A genial sci-fi action comedy that offers plenty of fun for fanboy types.
This powerful doc chronicles the dismally unjust aftermaths of two recent juvenile sexual-assault cases in the U.S.
The result is interesting enough, but feels a bit overextended at feature length considering the limited insight afforded.
An entertaining overview of the famed heiress' colorful history to date, drawing on an extensive trove of archival materials and the subject's own testimony.
movie_title: Nothing Left Unsaid: Gloria Vanderbilt & Anderson Cooper (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An assertively nasty frontier morality tale likely to win some cult admiration while repelling anyone looking for the return of wholesome Randolph Scott-type oaters.
This is no starry-eyed, heart-on-sleeve flashback but a low-key, respectful one, no less appealing for its relative reserve.
This watchable but middling drama tackles a worthy, relatable subject without quite figuring out what to say about it.
Even for a movie whose tail-chasing insubstantiality is pretty much "the joke," there's just not a lot of there there, to paraphrase Gertrude Stein.
An ensemble piece that breaks no new ground in themes or execution, but is pleasingly accomplished on all levels.
It's a fanboy's highlight reel of homages, without any of the credibility or context that made most of the films [Zombie is] inspired by so fine.
In dire need of additional voices that might substantiate Albert's account, and rendered suspect by their conspicuous absence.
Polished and clever, though not quite so engrossing or memorable as one might have hoped ...
A flavorsome documentary appreciation of the first Pulitzer-awarded food critic's culturally adventuresome palate.
An efficiently engineered suspenser, with solid performances and a tight pace.
Ultimately there's an intriguing arc here that rewards patience.
A 13-year-old nomadic Mongolian girl breaks a traditional role's gender barrier in this entertaining documentary.
Its initial promise dissipates in a muddle of repetitious phantasmagoria and too little narrative or character development.
Though never outright dull, "A Haunting in Cawdor" manages to provide few incidents of genuine interest while leaving potentially rewarding character and thematic elements unexplored.
An effective variation on stalker/home-invasion thriller themes.
A prankishly entertaining documentary well-suited for people who think they don't like documentaries.
Joey Kuhn's feature debut is impressively polished, but its burnished surface is more highly worked than the unevenly satisfying drama beneath.
A dramatic microcosm of the age-old conflict between progress and tradition.
Despite occasional narrative gaps, "Check It" is consistently compelling, with a brisk pace and vivid personalities making up for the occasional unanswered question.

This aptly colorful documentary doesn't provide all that much insight into the act's history, and the human conflicts aren't fully illuminated, either. But it's fun entering these performers' universe even with a less than all-access pass.

"AWOL" holds attention with its strong lead performances, nicely etched support turns, and nuanced portrait of a downwardly mobile "heartland" Caucasian America too seldom portrayed in movies given the large chunk of the populace it encompasses.

There's undeniable curiosity value to the subject. But once its flashback aspects are exhausted, "Pose" doesn't prove all that revealing or substantial, its last third feeling like a padded over-stretch of thin material.
A droll ostensible mystery whose investigation (let alone resolution) takes a back seat to the revealing eccentricities of characters and communities encountered en route.
Well timed for an election year even more charged with divisive rhetoric than usual, "Accidental Courtesy" offers an entertaining and inspirational message of rapprochement ...
movie_title: Accidental Courtesy: Daryl Davis, Race & America (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Even a possible UFO invasion can't stop a married couple from bickering as usual in this irksome relationship drama.
Anita Rocha da Silveira's arresting debut feature is a fever dream of adolescent sexuality with a retro giallo flavor.

It does what it does quite capably ... maintaining a muscular, splattery propulsion that never descends into campily excessive gore or any other silliness despite the occasional flat line and plausibility lapse.

"Another Evil" is somewhat unpredictable and nicely played, but so low-key that the comedy as well as everything else feels almost too modest for feature scale; it has the throwaway, anecdotal tenor of a droll short.

Gordon-Levitt is so good he compensates for the film's lacks, even if he can't erase them... 50/50 isn't quite worthy of this performance, but that doesn't mean it isn't occasionally elevated toward something special by encompassing it.
Songbirds is tough-mindedly striking on several levels. Its protagonists seem not exploited or manipulated, but fully engaged by their curious autobiographical mini-musical opportunity.
My Afternoons with Margueritte itself is hardly brain food for viewers-it's more like a still-warm, home-baked cookie, celluloid comfort food.
movie_title: La t√™te en friche (My Afternoons with Margueritte) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: When most popcorn flicks wear their preposterousness on their sleeve, here's a rare one that can, even should convince you it's smart, heartfelt, real-world-grounded entertainment while still requiring a massive suspension of disbelief.
A muscular exercise in brutal, relentless peril.
Portraying a cutthroat business in which little is "fair," "Don't Think Twice" acknowledges the bloodshed, but applies the razor with enough empathetic delicacy to earn its cautiously upbeat fade.
Meticulous in its small-scale period detail, but never feels like more than an vaguely prankish anecdote in story or thematic terms.
Those expecting insight into Robbins' life or career, let alone the overall self-help industry, will be disappointed by this atypically non-investigative Joe Berlinger documentary.
movie_title: Tony Robbins: I Am Not Your Guru (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There's not much real suspense stirred here by a premise that straddles recent found-footage thrillers and "Rear Window."
This long-shelved comedy proves a disappointing mix of onscreen talent, uneven social satire and juvenile humor.
The mix of levity, serious themes, marquee names and archival materials in Ferne Pearlstein's entertaining, thought-provoking documentary should find primarily broadcast buyers in numerous markets.
A very useful addition to public discourse at any time. But it's particularly so during this election year ...
Too derivative and not stylish enough to merit any special championing, as indie B-horror movies go, it's nonetheless nicely crafted enough to rate a cut above the low-expectation median.
The writer-director's seemingly random yet never aimless narrative avoids predictable sentimental notes as well as any explicit backstory, leaving us to fill in the blanks.
A supremely self-conscious genre exercise in which character and emotional depth don't seem to be on the very meta menu.
A psychological thriller requires some psychology as well as thrills, two things almost entirely absent from Gut.
A dramatized real-life scandal of 1980s prep-school drug dealing plays like a tepid compilation of fictive cliches in The Preppie Connection.

Nicely crafted, The Hedgehog seldom aims to be more than a pleasant low-key diversion-at which it succeeds-so it's jolting when the story pulls an abrupt late turn that casts everything in a more serious, ambitious light.
Neither very plausible nor scary, this found-footage exercise is nonetheless entertaining enough for a spell ...
It's hectic, unsubtle, borderline cartoonish.
[An] insufferable mishmash of interwoven segments - aimless in themselves, even more so as a whole - almost entirely concerned with bodily functions and bodily fluids.

While "Carpinteros" is strong enough in atmosphere and assembly, it's limited by characters who aren't developed with great complexity, and a climax that pours on a little too much credulity-stretching hyperbole.
This well-crafted doc makes for an absorbingly bizarre footnote. One suspects we are living in a historical epoch that is going to provide many such footnotes for some time to come.
"Wait for Your Laugh" pays fond tribute to a tireless trooper whom generations have known mostly as a wisecracking second banana often funnier than the bigger stars she supported.
Too much of "11/8/16" feels superficial and unmemorable, despite the range of talents of the filmmakers and the interviewee demographics.
The Sorbos, and benefactor Hannity, eventually soften their scare tactics in old-school tearjerking and a tech/design package that's above-average for the genre.
Revenge for the death of family members is a frequent boilerplate hook for mid-budget action movies, and that formula could hardly get a more perfunctory recycling than in "Acts of Vengeance."

Though it drifts off into the ozone at the end, for most of its running time, "Never Here" is a low-key but effective psychological thriller which flirts with that looming issue of the social-media age: privacy, and the invasion thereof.
A somewhat pulpy drama, but it's effective nonetheless.
It eventually summons up enough seriocomic neo-noir perversity to comprise a fun, semi-guilt-free ride.
An eccentric mix of veteran actors, Southern Gothicism and neo-noir lends "Cold Moon" a certain charm as a ghostly revenge thriller.
The first 90 minutes or so here are gold ... even if fans might wish for more detail on the dizzying number of fabled bands Clapton formed and/or played with over a 10-year span.
movie_title: Eric Clapton: A Life in 12 Bars (2017)

movie_review_blurb: ... "Realive" ultimately aims to be all about matters of the heart, and in that realm [writer/director Mateo] Gil's imagination proves disappointingly limited.

An earnest and well-crafted attempt at course-correction, straying from stock slasher recyclage to provide a different story that actually connects a few dots in the very tangled cinematic "Chainsaw" universe to date.
Mehta's freely imagined biopic provides a fascinating Rorschach of a figure who is, unfortunately, truly a man for our times.
A likably ramshackle, seemingly semi-improvised "free adaptation" of co-scenarist/star Adrian Schiop's semi-autobiographical novel about his experiences in Bucharest's Roma slum.
movie_title: Soldiers. A Story from Ferentari (Soldatii. Poveste din Ferentari) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: But the complex overall themes here are dealt with in such abrupt fashion that their treatment ultimately feels superficial. Still, you can hardly indict Onah for trying to make complex themes briskly palatable.
Packing a lot into a short narrative time span without seeming overstuffed, "The Journey" comes close to mawkish contrivance now and then but always stops short.
Few stage staples from 90 years ago would easily translate to the screen today, yet R.C. Sherriff's once near-ubiquitous "Journey's End" proves potent as ever in this sturdy new adaptation ...
Goodall remains an unassuming character whose apparent rock-steadiness ... underlines the conviction of her hard-won knowledge.
Though at first glance this ironically-sweet-and-very-sour mix might seem unappetizing, even repellent, it soon becomes fascinating in its oddball complexity
movie_title: Birdboy: The Forgotten Children (Psiconautas, los ni√±os olvidados) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As a ripe chunk of pure baroque atmosphere, this lushly staged costume chiller is a fragrant beauty indeed.
Dangles something fun, only to deliver something sober, neither angle well-realized enough to make a satisfying whole.
There have been plenty of good surfing documentaries, but very few good dramas about the sport - a short list on which "Breath" instantly earns a prominent spot.
"Mary Goes Around" handles its story beats with a canny mixture of rueful humor, warmth and realism.

Apparently moviemaking keeps getting easier while writing keeps getting harder - "Wetlands" being yet another example of a film whose surface technical polish can only do so much to gloss over the coarse, clumsy screenplay that flummoxes its cast.
Greer proves a resourceful comedienne, as usual, and a colorful array of supporting characters are nicely turned. The film's biggest single asset, however, is newcomer Doheny ...
This is a fetishistically precise recreation of a dead retro style, with no substance on the menu beyond the second-hand or accidental.
movie_title: Let the Corpses Tan (Laissez bronzer les cadavres!) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An initially absorbing, increasingly exasperating study of a family man whose actions grow inexplicable and indefensible after it's discovered he has a brain tumor.
Mostly it plays as a somber drama about grief, guilt and self-loathing, with both lead figures shell-shocked in their way.
"Hochelaga" is trickily structured and flamboyantly staged almost to a self-conscious fault, but nonetheless likewise rewards with a rich cinematic banquet.
movie_title: Hochelaga, Land of Souls (Hochelaga terre des √¢mes) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Practically every character is an argument for mercy killing in this bilious tale, which holds attention despite its somewhat rough-hewn assembly.
Cuena's neutral tone does little to maximize the black comedy or suspense in the story, making for a film with a great hook that plays as just a mildly outr√© divertissement.
... [Rita Moreno's] unpredictable performance in an underwritten role gooses things to an amiable degree.
So long as you turn your thinking cap off, this high-energy enterprise will provide plenty of less-than-highbrow fun.
A promising buildup is eroded by too many rote jump scares, leading to a conventionally hectic and silly climax further undermined by an inappropriately campy, late-arriving performance.
Though it may leave audiences with a fair number of questions unanswered, "The Cage Fighter" is engrossing and notably well-packaged within its limitations.
ShadowHunter [is] a grade-C actioner that bypassed a theatrical release and is bowing on Showtime.
"Summer of '84" is only cute and competent enough to be diverting; it's neither funny nor scary enough to leave a lasting impression.
Mostly the film trades in an agreeably old-school form of cinematic espionage intrigue.
Anyone with a taste for Nicolas Cage in full gonzo mode should get some fun out of its fever-dream progress.
Siblings Rodrigo and Sebastian Barriuso's first feature feels maudlin and contrived, even though it's based on their own father's experience ...
In the end, there's not enough of distinction or substance to make this absurdist family comedy with a haunted-house angle feel like more than a short's worth of ideas stretched too thin.

Not an especially pointed commentary about race or anything else, this lively, unpleasant seriocomedy nonetheless does very well at capturing the queasiness of being alone and uneasy at a party you immediately know you won't fit into.

There's a curious lack of credibility and urgency in this big-screen adaptation, the kind of respectable near-miss that can happen when worthy talent apply themselves to a project they're just not ideally suited for.
A movie whose glass is half empty - maybe it's just not possible to have a story about a 5-year-old's de facto stalker that isn't sure what it (or we) should think about the matter.
The film's edge, if not its worthiness, is slightly dulled by an over-slick approach that in the end makes it feel less like reportage than a first-class fundraising video.
Despite a few good moments, this well-intentioned seriocomedy mostly wobbles between crude yocks, lame generation-gap humor and sentimental cliche.

Everyone is allowed a misfire once in a while. It's just too bad Urushadze's had to follow his highest-profile effort to date with this odd and off-key work, subjecting it to more attention - and disappointment - than it would have otherwise have gotten.
This ingenious gizmo will ... delight Maddin fans, or anyone else who enjoys games played with and about old movies.
A good-natured delight.

Damiens floats this enterprise with just the right amount of harried Everyman appeal. De France hits a bit too abrasive a screwball note at first, but her performance gains charm in equal measure to its chemistry with her co-star.
movie_title: Just to Be Sure (√îtez-moi d'un doute) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This quietly forceful drama, its power heightened by both writer-director Hanna Slak and lead thesp Leon Lucev's judicious restraint, is all the stronger for avoiding the hand-wringing melodrama its subject might easily have elicited.
An entertaining documentary, though its thesis isn't entirely convincing.

There's plenty of intrigue on the New Mexico ranch our heroine is shunted off to in "Kepler's Dream," but little suspense is wrung from it in this tepid family drama adapted from a well-reviewed YA novel by Juliet Bell.

Given the gradually upticking arc of his opuses' IMDb ratings to date, Woodward should finally score a 6 out of 10 sometime next year. He's got the perspiration part down; surely inspiration can't hold out much longer.
movie_title: Gangster Land (In the Absence of Good Men) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A film that somehow manages to be fairly watchable, yet nonetheless really needed intervention from the conceptual stage onward.
Fast-paced and colorful enough to rate as a solid guilty pleasure.
Viewers seeking titillation are much less likely to be satisfied than those who'll appreciate this surreal, aesthetically bold gizmo as the latest left-turn in its creator's idiosyncratic career.
Surely the best Yank-directed horror movie about English blokes terrorized by monsters in Romania-posing-as-Sweden that you'll see this year.
The care and affection with which Mainwood and his collaborators (notably animation director Peter Dodd and art director Robin Shaw) adapt already endearing material carries the day.
Solidly pro in overall packaging yet cliched, pedestrian and indistinct in specific contributions, this thriller never finds (let alone raises) its own pulse.
While it would be unfair to call this feature a two-hour compilation of crying scenes, it comes awfully close to being just that.
[A] slick and well-paced if uninspired time-filler ...
Pedestrian (at best) in content and execution, including listless, sometimes inept staging of key action elements.
Compelling enough while you're watching it, frustrating then forgettable once it ends, this is a work that wouldn't command much attention if it came from any other director.
Good music and good company make "Itzhak" a pleasure, though those seeking a methodical career overview should look elsewhere than this genial personality sketch of the world-famous violinist.
Artfully assembled and often entertaining, the diverse whole nonetheless doesn't quite gel, with the film finally coming off as somewhat pretentious and heavy-handed.
Those who can roll with its measured pace and playfully nonsensical story will find the sum impact drolly diverting.
Tanscends mere bad-taste humor to become one of the great jet-black comedies about suburbia, destined for the same cult-classic status accorded "The Stepford Wives," "Parents" and "Heathers."
Produced as a vehicle for co-starring friends Ellen Page and Kate Mara, "Mercy" serves them both well, with critical support likely to help the film find an audience despite its challenging themes.
The endearing, guileless personalities of the two principals constitute much of the film's appeal.
Despite (or even partly because of) that diffident air, a portrait of the artist emerges that's complex, somewhat mysterious, but ultimately quite winning.
Entertaining if a bit conventional in its anecdotal structure and slightly cutesy tone, these 95 minutes should appeal to the same public that happily spends half the day reading the Sunday Times ...
Equal parts "Taken"-style thriller and old-school marital-arts/triad-meller homage, it's expertly crafted good fun that should appeal to genre fans across many borders.
This uneven but watchable effort stars Clark Freeman as a man of many phobias whose terror of death leads him to find out more about the afterlife than he wanted.
As another in-joke whose punchline probably wouldn't be that funny even if there was one, it's unlikely to expand Byington's small coterie of admirers.

A nonfiction-focused director and cinematographer frequently attracted to the intersection between artistic expression, nature, and spirituality (however unarticulated), Riedelsheimer is well-matched to Goldsworthy's methods and interests.

After a promising start, this enterprising but overstuffed endeavor drifts increasingly into a muddled sci-fi mystical horror hybrid that only gets more confusing as it grows more thematically ambitious.
Though there's not a whole lot of plot here, Ebeltoft makes a virtue of writing economy, and director Rod Blackhurt maintains considerable interest as well as a consistent low hum of tension.
We're stuck for eternity with two perfectly decent people who, it seems, just aren't very interesting company. Not even for each other.

If you don't think too hard about it afterward, "Dig Two Graves" impresses on the whole, its general flavor closer to something like a spookier "To Kill a Mockingbird" than it is to Stephen King territory ...
Parents may feel a bit uneven and over-ambiguous as a whole, but its off-center mix of slightly black comedy and drama is never less than interesting.

Not everyone will enjoy this slide down a narrative garbage chute lined with thorns. But viewers and programmers with a taste for midnight-movie outrageousness will cotton to its mix of sleaze, quease and bad-taste absurdism.
It certainly does have a grotesque stranger-than-fiction tale to tell, one that will duly keep any viewer with an ambulance-chasing bone in their body somewhat guiltily riveted to the tube.

"I want to get to the place where I have no strength to hide anything," she says of her work. Yet as a portrait of real life, "Bobbi Jene" doesn't require her to be very revealing, and she doesn't volunteer it.
One would like to spread the golden sunlight that suffuses Malmberg's photography on a piece of bread, with prociutto, and have it for lunch.

With its generically bright look and seeming disinterest in suspenseful atmosphere or set pieces, "Madre" bungles most of its admittedly derivative potential as a combination "nanny from Hell" movies and "Rosemary's Baby."
"The Archer" is decently enough staged, paced, and acted, though it's never gritty or shocking enough to risk being taken as seriously as it sometimes seems to demand.

Commingling elements of fiction and documentary is the trickiest kind of creative alchemy - a challenge "Flesh and Blood" rises to with results that are consistently interesting but somewhat awkward nonetheless.

This atmospheric and keenly observed feature captures with bittersweet lyricism the pathos of growing up subject to the whims of free-spirited grownups who themselves could use some adult supervision.

There are no puppies, kittens or baby bunnies in This Beautiful Fantastic. That said, however, any restraint before the altar of adorableness is abandoned in writer-director Simon Aboud's sophomore feature.

Offers another theoretically noble if B-grade and somewhat propagandistic attempt to shed light on a murky historical chapter - while falling into a similar puddle of romance-novel cliches from which it can't get up.
Stewart keeps screaming gamely, but the corny horrors she endures are all too tangibly visited on her by a bunch of young performers in black robes and demon makeup ...
This fascinating documentary by co-directors Joseph Martin and Sam Blair finds a stranger-than-fiction hook for probing [a] disturbing global trend.

Though this suspense drama about two small-town youths who run afoul of fleeing big-city criminals feels a couple story beats short of a satisfying whole, it's admirably well-crafted within its mostly savvy limitations.
Never quite finds a distinctive narrative slant or atmosphere of its own. Nonetheless, director-co-scenarist Andrew C. Erin's film will pass the time tolerably enough for genre fans.
A slick but thoroughly uninspired helming debut for veteran visual effects supervisor and second-unit director Robert Legato.

The very definition of a documentary crowd-pleaser, "It's Not Yet Dark" provides an appropriately poignant and upbeat account of Irish filmmaker Simon Fitzmaurice's inspiring triumph over physical limitations.
A lively and engaging glimpse at a Manila maternity ward where overcrowding and limited technological resources have forced some solutions that may not be ideal, but are admirable nonetheless.
This glossy doc uncovers very little conflict or depth in a personality more colorful than it is interesting, at least as presented here.
"Lake Bodom" is not so much a slasher film as a meta-slasher film, toying knowingly with genre conventions and touchstones.
"Caught" provides a fascinating albeit extreme illustration of the intersection between fame, greed, copyright and technology in the internet age.
movie_title: Kim Dotcom: Caught in the Web (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Gripping and discomfiting, this first directorial feature by the veteran editor is the kind of diaristic inquiry that can seem self-indulgent but here sports a fearlessness that transcends vanity - at times it's downright unflattering.
Often feels like a narrative feature - one that engrosses even as its complex central figure defies full understanding.
movie_title: Forbidden Games: The Justin Fashanu Story (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Shelton and Duplass lend every significant character a sense of uncontrived evolution, leading to a finale that is stirring precisely for being so tentative and reserved.
What matters most is that the principally unchanged story of survival in colonial French Guiana remains a compelling one ...

At first glance the film makes a knockout impression, at once showy and enigmatic. But as it proceeds, dishing up more idiosyncratic imagery but absolutely no insight, the spell may begin to pall for many viewers.
"Goon" was a keeper. The perhaps prophetically named "Last" isn't exactly 101 minutes in the penalty box, but it's a disappointing throwaway.

An episodic endeavor enlivened only so much by decent comedy talent dealing with absurdist situations in a hip deadpan that grows monotonous, with dialogue that too often sounds less-than-inspirationally improvised.
An intellectually untaxing guilty pleasure that's skillfully enough made to stir up little guilt.
''Ice Cream Truck" goes down rather easy, the clashing tactics holding a perverse charm when the pacing or story focus seems to drift for minutes at a time.

Those susceptible to off-kilter yet accessible humor in the general "Napoleon Dynamite" realm will ... find plenty to enjoy in this brightly produced tale of one very dim, alcoholic, blithely self-destructive amateur daredevil.
[A] twisty, compelling psychological study in thriller guise ...
Cross is very good at nuancing the hidden depths of a character whose precise "problem" is purposefully kept elusive in Farahani and Jason O'Leary's intelligent script.

Somewhere between "Jackass" and "Faces of Death" lies the queasy allure of "The Road Movie." Dmitrii Kalashnikov's feature is a found-footage compilation of clips shot by Russian dashboard cameras, then posted online.
Playwright Ian MacAllister-McDonald's debut feature is a refreshingly grounded, unsentimental yet empathetic slice of D-list teenage life that goes a bit overboard in its final act.

Watchable if never really scary or funny enough to leave a memorable impression, this middling endeavor should nonetheless pull in a fair number of home-viewing horror fans with its offbeat theme and lurid title.
"Awaken" is fine so long as it keeps us anticipating more. But when things wrap up too quickly, leaving too many dangling threads, there's a sense of letdown.
[A] feeble, somewhat amateurish if enthusiastic retread.

A watchable, albeit unsatisfying, vehicle for two stars who've now made a pair of movies together in which their skills constitute the main attraction, yet who aren't particularly well-served by either film.
Garishly colorful, packed with stars, legendary parties, and a wide streak of pathos, it's a singular life story entertainingly recounted in "The Fabulous Allan Carr."

Mixing sheer spectacle with modest but pleasing human-interest threads, Viktor Jakovleski's first directorial feature is a poetical, entrancing documentary that should delight niche viewers across many cultural borders.
An amiable, fast-paced entry that should win over fans.
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Thoroughly disarming and rewarding, despite a borderline-exasperating reluctance to fill in the most basic blanks regarding our subject's past and present circumstances.

Channels and sustains the energy of restless youth while communicating the distinctive qualities of a community that carried collectivist 1960s ideals into a new generation, even as it rejected any vestige of their hippie parents' music.
movie_title: Turn It Around: The Story of East Bay Punk (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Scant action arrives until the last half hour, and then it's frequently preposterous; with minor fine-tuning, some climactic peril here might easily play as slapstick.
[A] promising if imperfect debut feature.
Fails to elicit memorable work from any of its principal collaborators.
Its middling plot twists and atmospherics fail to ratchet up as much tension as Edo Van Breeman's score tries to evoke.
The film belatedly emerges as one of the stronger fictional statements on 9/11.
This culture-clash snapshot provides a moving if also mysterious portrait of fragile mental health snapping tether entirely amid the alien environs of blithe hedonism.
The intersection between crime thriller and horror is an interesting place to be, even if it doesn't fully pay off in Midnighters.
As a comedy, "The Feels" has considerable sprightly appeal, although it could have used slightly more assertive visual packaging.
The problem is that this watchable indie isn't all that funny, clever or surprising despite its outr√© premise.

"Becks" is the kind of modest, non-earthshaking indie enterprise that ends up being so satisfying mostly because it's about a character type familiar from real life but all too under-represented at the movies.
Seems destined to become one of those Yuletide perennials for people who like their holiday-themed entertainment as perversely un-wholesome as possible.
This latest effort from Turkish writer-helmer Tolga Karacelik is intriguing enough, but slow-moving and insufficiently atmospheric to stir as much mystery or tension as it should.
You don't need to have seen the movies [Biller is] paying cheeky homage to in order to enjoy Viva. But afterward, you'll probably want to.

A simple, universal parable played out in boldly imaginative (though not particularly high-tech) design terms, Brazilian animator Ale Abreu's second feature, The Boy and the World, is an enchanting visual treat.
movie_title: Boy and the World (O Menino e o Mundo) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Apart from its Iranian-American milieu, this innocuous romantic comedy is strictly formulaic.
Noisy battle scenes a la 'Transformers' and 'Starship Troopers' mar this pedestrian animated sequel to H.G. Wells' original story.
Some of "Chlorine's" scenes go for a pat lifestyle satire that can be diverting enough but feels secondhand. Elsewhere it makes wobbly overtures toward unearned dramatic poignancy ...
A campus comedy that tries to transcend its many formulaic elements with an insufficient dose of absurdism.
Period drama lacks the kind of galvanizing lead perf that might attract attention to an otherwise uninspired treatment, a la "La Vie en Rose."
An above-average little thriller rather than a near-great one.
A return to the cinema of adorable mental illness - something that, like the killer in a slasher movie, always seems to lurch back to life just when you think it's safely dead ...
This romantic-comedy roundelay gets better as it gradually moves away from comedy toward more sentimental material.
Good performances and quirky humor make this slick if less than fully satisfying mix of romantic comedy and mystery an easy sit.
Not only plays like the crassest possible mashup of "Harry Potter" and "Twilight" elements, but seems designed to make those franchises look like eternal monuments of world culture by comparison.
[The filmmakers] lend the film's overall impact the alert observational intelligence of a first-rate short story.
A long-forgotten, envelope-pushing figure of 1970s rock will be hard to forget again after Jobriath A.D.
Edet Belzberg's sweeping survey of global genocide is an impressive and artful cinematic thesis of palpable substance.
A frequently inspiring and exciting documentary.
Static and uninvolving despite a decent cast.
A bizarre and entertaining documentary about China's attempts to reprogram its Internet-addicted youth.
Cynthia Hill delivers a vivid portrait of one leading justice advocate and one survivor of horrific spousal abuse.
"Difret" presents an important message, albeit in rather clunky narrative terms.
So much of "Viktoria" heralds such a fascinating filmic sensibility that one eagerly looks forward to whatever Vitkova does next.
Somewhat baffling in retrospect, if actually rather bland and formulaic to watch.
This debut film by Belle and Sebastian singer-songwriter Stuart Murdoch is a slender exercise in self-conscious charm.
A somewhat grotesquely comic, very entertaining portrait of a man known to many as 'the Merchant of Death.'
The original's gradual buildup toward inspired outrageousness is replaced by immediately full-on gore-horror comedy in a broader, dumber Troma-style vein.
movie_title: Dead Snow 2: Red vs. Dead (D√∏d sn√∏ 2) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Those who suspect that EDM is possibly the most vapid form of 'alternative' music will have their suspicions confirmed by this 3D documentary.
Berit Madsen's documentary offers a leisurely, engaging portrait of a provincial Iranian teenager who dreams of becoming an astronaut.
Two petulant brats go on a singularly unrewarding road trip across the Serbian countryside in Mina Djukic's debut feature.

The potentially ludicrous story is handled artfully enough here to cast an eerie but not off-putting spell throughout, though the ultimate point is more than a tad murky, and the desired poignancy doesn't fully come across.
Mona Fastvold's consistently intriguing debut may leave audiences feeling it's all buildup and scant payoff.
Wingard wreaks havoc on another nuclear family in this giddily violent treat for genre fans.
The bright ideas begin to thin out, and the pic never quite recovers its footing.
Richard Ray Perez and Lorena Parlee co-direct a solidly inspiring portrait of the late agricultural workers' champion.
Only those scared of being bored to death need fear "Locker 13," an omnibus of horror stories that could hardly be more tame, talky and tepid, both individually and as a whole.
Writer-director-star Luke Moran's drama about Abu Ghraib is an ambitious if not particularly revealing debut.
Damon Maulucci and Keir Politz make a fine feature debut with this small, punchy drama.
Despite competent performances and packaging, dialogue and situations in Aimee Lagos' script are too routine to create much excitement.
Taken in a lighthearted spirit, it's all good fun, with well-handled if increasingly improbable action.
The prankster activists return to wage war against climate change in this amusing documentary.
Even those who get the joke here may find it wearing thin after a while.

Nothing feels fresh here - not even Christopher Plummer hamming it up as a crusty-coot grandpa - and Philip Martin's routinely polished direction only underscores the cliche-composting of Richard D'Ovidio's script.
Slick but derivative and forgettable on all levels.
The results are admirable in intent and sporadic effect, but still a mixed bag overall.
Impressive scenery and action elevate a tale of pre-colonial Maori warfare that is nonetheless brutal to the brink of monotony.
Liv Ullmann's worshipful but static adaptation of the classic Strindberg play fails to work as a film, despite impressive perfs.
Though a tad uneven, as a whole the documentary cannily juggles an overview of African-American history in general with the specifics of its photographic representation and talents.
movie_title: Through a Lens Darkly: Black Photographers and the Emergence of a People (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Even if you've tired of Takei's ubiquity online and onscreen, this campy but fond tribute is great fun.
A sloppy chiller about tourists falling prey to an online stalker in Bangkok that clumsily mixes slasher, sexploitation and supernatural elements.
As willfully lowbrow dumb fun goes, it's pretty painless.
[An] intriguing, above-average genre effort ...
Blood Junkie is pure retro-flavva'd silliness.

A middling real-time thriller that chronicles a fictive crisis for two Air Force personnel, who find themselves at loggerheads when they spot an apparent terrorist thousands of miles away on surveillance video.
There's enough material here for a half-hour short or a one-act play, but the character and plot reveals simply aren't complicated or surprising enough to justify feature length.
A cartoonish and crudely staged dramatization of a disturbing true crime.
An absorbing glimpse of a unique, largely forgotten showbiz chapter that spanned decades of great change in public tastes and popular media.
Skirting horror and black-comedy terrain without quite surrendering to either, the pic proves rather bracing even if it doesn't hold up to much plot-logic scrutiny.
"The Machine" works modestly well, but still wobbles trying to balance its "thinking man's sci-fi" aspirations against the need to placate less adventurous fans via standard action content.
This enjoyable ride should appeal to Alice Cooper's original fans, as well as those who came to him via the performers he influenced.

Though there might have been some real drama to tap in following some seniors' efforts to reconnect with their long-lost loves, Cassaday either doesn't find any such intrigue, or didn't bother looking for it.
Makes [its] point so strenuously and repetitiously that it becomes a tad exhausting.
Its essential contrivance works against the earnest emotions it's aiming for ...
This potentially intriguing concept is given disappointingly bland, flat treatment ...
Real suspense and shocks are MIA in a movie that's eventful but lacks the atmospherics needed to be scary.

[The film] offers a potentially intriguing study in high-minded political/moral obstinacy, but feels too claustrophobic -- and, finally, tediously like a one-man window on great events -- to fully come to dramatic life.
A slick, entertaining survey of electronic gaming's history to date.
Its eventual reach for warm-and-fuzzy emotional catharsis rings hollow among characters that never become more than disagreeably shallow products of unexamined privilege.
The result feels like a class project (as indeed it began), stretched but not deepened to feature length.
Even for those most receptive to the tongue-in-cheek tone here, McKee and Silvertson's in-joke will likely rate just middling on the scale of subversive hilarity.
Its extraordinary story can hardly help but involve and outrage.
Cutter Hodierne makes an accomplished feature debut with this very well-crafted, empathetic hijacking drama.
Strife and sexual humor reign in this energetic romp, one of Bill Plympton's best longform animated works.
Documentaries don't come any bigger-hearted than Blood Brother.
A confidently engineered, propulsive piece of intelligent action cinema.
This Dimension pickup is a hectic, sometimes hilarious guilty pleasure that should delight genre geeks.

Nguyen's partial self-awareness of his new movie's camp value -- encompassing brief incorporation of zombies -- only makes it an effortful, half-understood in-joke rather than the guiltily pleasurable unintentional joke that was Birdemic: Shock and Terror.
This unconventional, unsettling couple-on-the-run tale works best as an exercise in ambiguous atmosphere.
A middling drama that tries to combine elements of Rambo with serious treatment of soldiers' post-traumatic stress disorder and vague political commentary.
A generally effective sequel.

A pretty good buildup to OK payoff without any real surprises en route makes Dark Skies feel just enough above average to make one wish it had one memorable spark of conceptual inspiration up its sleeve.
Especially for a movie whose title is in the first person, "Once Upon a Time Was I, Veronica" doesn't make much of an effort to get into the head of its protagonist ...
A straightforward, solidly crafted inspirational tale that should appeal to quality broadcasters.

So involving that one might not notice until afterward that little in the way of a unified theme emerges to turn Joseph Levy's feature into something more than a semi-random survey of restaurant life.

The gentle tenor is abetted by the easygoing pace, Stephen Daltry's attractive chamber score and Heathcote's lensing, which captures the surroundings' pastoral beauty without going for picture-postcard prettiness.
Snaking through a tangle of interlocking ideas, threads and events, it never quite finds a unified focus.
A likable, intimate documentary kept from being too grim by the leads' good-humored personalities ...
Feels secondhand and contrived.
"Halley" isn't particularly satisfying as a narrative or character study, and the profundity or blankness of its meaning is entirely up to the viewer.
Offbeat, but also frequently off-key and somewhat off-putting.
Tinatin Gurchiani's accomplished first feature The Machine Which Makes Everything Disappear offers an impressionistic, somewhat poetical view of current life in her native former Soviet territory.
movie_title: The Machine Which Makes Everything Disappear (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Warmly enjoyable.
Less turns out to be much more for S-VHS, a sequel to last year's uneven indie horror omnibus V/H/S; this one is shorter and has fewer segments, but also earns a much higher batting average.
Austenland doesn't really satirize Austen's world (or fans) so much as use them as a pretext for a mixture of middling burlesque and routine romantic comedy.

Though all the performances are very good, much of Look's entertainment value comes from an impressive tech package that captures the shifting fashions of swinger-favored pop-culture garishness over the pic's roughly 25-year period.
It boasts no character insight, social commentary or discernible overall point to counter charges that this is just a redundant wallow in arted-up, torture-porn cruelty.
If these loose threads and underdeveloped aspects leave American Mary less than fully satisfying, it's still a novel ride that confidently mixes horror, humor and offbeat character fillips.
The thoughtful overall assembly finally achieves just enough gravitas to make the pic's economical runtime seem just right.
A small, unremarkable but quite funny tale of revivified dead people overtaking a university building over holiday break.
[The film] quickly becomes far more than mere visual accompaniment, immediately joining the rarefied roster of great all-dance films.
Entertaining if ultimately depressing.
An unnerving home-invasion thriller.
A well-intentioned drama that would play much better if it didn't feel the need to make that message quite so heavy-handedly obvious.
A comedy built on the amusement value of stupid people that is itself too stupid to be funny.
There's not a whole lot of dramatic punch to what seems as much a camera-friendly stunt as a personal/political statement.
Rob Grant's Canadian feature pulls off something that's harder to do than it looks, namely the comedy of escalating disaster, in which each new mishap tops the last in bad-taste splatstick.
A lethargic and uninspired take that aims to be something different, but ultimately isn't.
Todd Douglas Miller's engrossing documentary covers the triumphant discovery - and government seizure - of the world's largest, most complete T-Rex skeleton.
The quest for the Midas Box never seems like more than a poor man's plot-engine substitute for Tolkien's One Ring.
movie_title: The Adventurer: The Curse of the Midas Box (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This brutally monotonous actioner centers around an all-female fight-to-the-death contest, but viewers of either gender may find themselves dying of boredom.
Arrives at a destination that may strike some as too pat, but getting there is nonetheless consistently interesting.
"Hollywood Seagull" updates Chekhov's play by turning it into a tepid soap opera set in a gated clifftop Malibu compound inhabited by a bitter ex-movie star, her family and associates.
Intriguing if ultimately less than satisfying.

This exciting assemblage of archival and interview materials recalls the considerable influence (and sometime public trivialization) of the 1990s riot grrrl movement while showcasing the role of its co-founder and most charismatic leader.
This year's crowded field of Snow White movies has a winner, at least in terms of quality, in Pablo Berger's delightful Blancanieves.
Genially cartoonish but also rather sweet.
Her enduring appeal is amply documented in myriad vintage photos and clips deployed, while erstwhile collaborators and latter-day admirers add their two cents.
A body-horror opus that will satisfy genre fans who like to be grossed out, but doesn't have much to offer on any other count.
Markus Zusak's international bestseller The Book Thief has been brought to the screen with quiet effectiveness and scrupulous taste by director Brian Percival and writer Michael Petroni.
Ocular succeeds in keeping the viewer's bearings unsettled as the helmer's effective building of dread curdles into a series of narrative twists as dislocating as an Escher-drawn staircase.
The books' juggling of tricky tonal and narrative devices translates into a screen result less clever than arbitrary and silly.
Turning its low budget into a self-mocking plus, this umpteenth 'Mad Max'-style dystopian actioner delivers trashy fun for genre fans.
Greg Camalier's debut feature offers a worthy if sometimes ponderous take on a significant slice of U.S. popular music history.
A rather turgid ghost story with a simultaneously murky and silly take on the afterlife.
movie_title: I Will Follow You Into The Dark (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Polished but unmemorable.
Hangs a tad slackly between thriller and procedural, but still holds attention throughout.
Engaging personalities and lively, good-looking assembly make T.C. Johnstone's inspirational sports docu a crowdpleaser.
There may be no great originality on display in You're Next, the latest indie horror opus from Adam Wingard, but there's certainly plenty of energy.

Both the kindest and most damning thing you can say about "The Fifth Estate" is that it primarily hobbles itself by trying to cram in more context-needy material than any single drama should have to bear.
A definitive document for anyone who's ever hoisted the devil-horn fingers in metalhead solidarity.
Writer-director Geeta Mohandas makes a quietly effective debut with this Indian road drama.
A fitting memorial to Elmore Leonard, "Life of Crime" reps one of the most faithful of the many adaptations of the author's work.
A zombie by any other name is still a zombie in this utterly routine horror pic.
The heavyweight champ's controversial political views are reexamined in this stirring, fascinating documentary.
Bittersweet, charming yet often very thorny.
Feels like a somewhat superficial, "authorized" bio that nonetheless holds attention via its surfeit of archival materials and input from diverse interviewees.
movie_title: Filthy Gorgeous: The Bob Guccione Story (2013)

movie_review_blurb: This cheerfully silly action fantasy is unpretentious fun best suited to younger viewers.
This silly throwback to the post-'Psycho' shockers of the '60s offers a sluggish giallo-like murder mystery spiked with grotesque sadism.
A dreary affair that will thrill undiscriminating fans of torture-porn horror and nobody else.
The prior installments weren't very good movies, and it should surprise few that this last one is the worst of the lot.
movie_title: Atlas Shrugged: Who Is John Galt? (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Earnest, solid if somewhat plodding at times ...
Alan White's polished but pedestrian pic mines little real suspense and few surprises from a formulaic script.
